> WHERE:  City Services Committee of the Board of Supervisors, City =
Hall,
Rm. 263
>
> The SFLNC needs your support for a proposal that could have huge =
benefits
> for the entertainment scene in San Francisco.
>
> Supervisor Aaron Peskin has introduced a resolution encouraging State
> Assemblymember Mark Leno to develop legislation that could extend the =
last
> call for alcohol in bars, restaurants and nightclubs in California's
> largest Cities.  This will give San Franciscans and visitors to our =
City
> similar rights to those enjoyed in New York, Chicago, Miami, New =
Orleans
> and other large cities that allow alcohol sales after 2am.  This will =
also
> provide a much needed boost to our local entertainment scene and =
economy.
>
> The SFLNC first introduced this resolution at the Entertainment
Commission,
> which voted unanimously to support it.  Please read the resolution
>
here:(<http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/materials/=
040
057.pdf>http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/materials=
/04
0057.pdf).
>
> In your email to our elected officials, it is crucial to include in =
the
> subject line the words "Support Later Last Call Hours".  Supervisors =
do
not
> always read every email but they do count those for and against an
> issue.  If you wish to contact your District Supervisor by phone or =
fax,
> contact info is available at:
>
<http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_index.asp>http://www.sfgov.org/site/b=
dsu
pvrs_index.asp
>
> Here are some important points about this proposal:
>
> * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world class =
city
>
> * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the city =
and
the
> state of California
>
> * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other major
cities
>
> * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later last =
call
> hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of alcohol
> related traffic fatalities.
>
> * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at restaurants,
bars,
> or nightclubs
>
> * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in supermarkets =
or
> liquor stores
>
> * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
> districts zoned for late night businesses.
>
> * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.
>

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040204172428.GJ538@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org

In-Reply-To: <54.21c1a11a.2d521ade@aol.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

quoth DJBigDaddyG@aol.com:
> out of the 2 mixers witch one is better the pioneer one is like 600$
> more money but Behringer says they got more FX's then pioneer... i was
> looking to buy a new mixer and this is what i am thinking about they
> both look the same and i think they even play the same... i need some
> feed back please..

Behringer makes a nice business out of ripping off technology from their
rivals and using it to build nearly identical products. I'd suggest
going with neither: the Pioneer sucks to begin with, for reasons too
numerous to list here. If you want a mixer that'll last you for more
than a couple of years, go with Rane, Vestax, or A&H.

And while I'm not too fond of Pioneer's mixers, I would definitely
recommend their EFX-500 effects processor. Match that with a solid mixer
that has an effects loop (the Rane MP44's is sweet) and you're set.

Good luck,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV34kJjjK1kuZ00056519@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Feb 2004 17:55:28.0208 (UTC) FILETIME=[12CCA500:01C3EB48]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

Exactly. Remember something - that blinky button the Pioneer is EVIL. It's a
handicap that shitty dj's who can't spin use to cover up their inabilities.
I could shoot any dj that thinks the flange effect needs to be on every mix.
More so if this is going to be an investment that's supposed to last buy a
Rane or Allen and Heath. Fact is when you (if you ever) get to play a large
venue you're going to find a Rane or an Allen and Heath. Suddenly your much
loved effects are gone and you have to actually play without masking a
deficit in skill.

What it comes down to is that neither model of mixer you speak of is durable
nor commonly used except for small clubs or special requests from gimp dj's.

Buy a REAL mixer. Walk away from the effects.

:: r ::

Subject: [sfraves]Reclaim the Streets Renegade 

What do y'all have to say about this?  I found it on Groundscore.

Saturday, Feb 14th 2004. Noon. Haight+Stanyan.

Reclaim the Streets San Francisco has planned a street-pirate street-party 
for Valentines Day. Price: FREE!

Show up at Haight and Stanyan in SF, at the top of Haight street where it 
runs into Golden Gate Park. We will meet at 12 Noon (BE ON TIME!) and 
gather, then march to the location of the street party (this will remain 
undisclosed until we get there). Then, fun will ensue.

There will be electronic music (breaks, psytrance, house, maybe more), art, 
poetry, dancing, punk rock, pirates, bicycles, and wacky reclaim the streets 
stunt type things! Be creative, plan our own fun. Also, BYOB.

Watch the rts-sf website (under construction) for promotional materials, and 
help promote this event. Tell your friends, invite your lovers, etc. Also, 
feel free to make your own stickers and flyers, put them up, talk up the 
RTS. (especially at your home!)

http://sfrts.tribe.net
www.rts-sf.org

PUBLICIZE WIDELY!

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SFLNC:  Support Later Last Call Hours

Some people refuse to accept personal responsibility.  Didn't you notice 
the homeless?

Governmental control isn't about big brother doing bad things to us.  It's 
about the people getting together and deciding to enact rules for their 
community.  If this legislation goes into effect, it won't override local 
ordinances.

I don't like the extended hours proposal - it seems like a bad idea to me, 
mostly for reasons ak already covered.  We'll see what happens tho..

>From: aK [mailto:aK@hard-grooves.com]

>Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC: Support Later Last Call Hours
>
>
>heya
>
>hmmm. . . not that I don't support the SFLNC. . . most people know I do. . .
>
>but one of the last things I'd ever support would be anything regarding
>alcohol, or something that lets people drink MORE.
>
>I think (or would guess) that the reason there is a "last call" for alcohol,
>and restrictions on selling alcohol after certain hours, would be for the
>safety of the public.
>Realistically, these limitations are a somewhat sensible time to have people
>stop drinking. More than likely tho, even with those times, people still end
>up driving home under the influence and are much much much more likely to
>hurt or kill any random innocent person on their obviously compromised drive
>home.
>
>with the amount of drunken driving these days. . . the last thing anyone
>really needs is to increase the likelihood of drunken accidents.
>I understand it may help the entertainment scene in SF. I just think it's
>just plain stupid to trade the potential lives of people for clubs to make
>more money.
>
>shit, everyone knows that one of the worst times to leave a party, is right
>when everone else is. With people drunk or on whatever, and the mass of them
>trying to go wherever at the same time, it can be a kind of dangerous chaos
>at times. No wonder every time I would go to a club or party, someone ALWAYS
>hit my car. . .
>
>I would hope that this attempt from the SFLNC isn't fueled by "donations"
>from people who would no doubt benefit from the passing of something like
>this. Too many people these days "sell out" for money. Not enuf people these
>days give a shit about the people they hurt doing it.
>
>I'm not a drinker, I hate alcohol. I've seen and been in cars with
>inebriated drivers and thankfully survived those experiences of going off
>the road, etc. I see people do horrible and stupid things due to alcohol
>moreso than any drug I've ever known of.
>
>Its similar to how the US covers up issues with things like tainted meat,
>etc. Because they gain financially from the distribution of it. It's all a
>very saddening thought.
>
>No matter what anyone says, the people involved supporting issues that lead
>to the destruction of lives and health of others are majorely the ones with
>the "bloody hands". Thats not saying that I don't support peoples freedom to
>decide for themselves. But bars and clubs are the "pushers" of one of the
>most dangerous chemicals used every day. And it's legal, despite the damage
>it does. Why ? Cuz it makes them money. . .
>
>I think it's a badd idea, and if I lived in SF I would write to my district
>supervisor in support AGAINST it. Other than that tho, I'm all for
>supporting clubs in ANY OTHER WAY (of which are many).
>
>aK

> > WHAT:  1. Write an email in support of extending last call hours for
>alcohol
> >               2. Come to the hearing at the Board of Supervisors
> >
> > WHEN: 1. Write the email now to the addresses listed below.
> >              2. Come to the hearing on Thursday, Feb 5th at 9:30 am.
> >
><http://sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_page.asp?id=13954>http://sfgov.org/site/bdsu
>pvrs_page.asp?id=13954
> >
> > WHERE:  City Services Committee of the Board of Supervisors, City Hall,
>Rm. 263
> >
> > The SFLNC needs your support for a proposal that could have huge benefits
> > for the entertainment scene in San Francisco.
> >
> > Supervisor Aaron Peskin has introduced a resolution encouraging State
> > Assemblymember Mark Leno to develop legislation that could extend the last
> > call for alcohol in bars, restaurants and nightclubs in California's
> > largest Cities.  This will give San Franciscans and visitors to our City
> > similar rights to those enjoyed in New York, Chicago, Miami, New Orleans
> > and other large cities that allow alcohol sales after 2am.  This will also
> > provide a much needed boost to our local entertainment scene and economy.
> >
> > The SFLNC first introduced this resolution at the Entertainment
>Commission,
> > which voted unanimously to support it.  Please read the resolution
> >
>here:(<http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/materials/040
>057.pdf>http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/materials/04
>0057.pdf).
> >
> > In your email to our elected officials, it is crucial to include in the
> > subject line the words "Support Later Last Call Hours".  Supervisors do
>not
> > always read every email but they do count those for and against an
> > issue.  If you wish to contact your District Supervisor by phone or fax,
> > contact info is available at:
> >
><http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_index.asp>http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsu
>pvrs_index.asp
> >
> > Here are some important points about this proposal:
> >
> > * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world class city
> >
> > * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the city and
>the
> > state of California
> >
> > * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other major
>cities
> >
> > * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later last call
> > hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of alcohol
> > related traffic fatalities.
> >
> > * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at restaurants,
>bars,
> > or nightclubs
> >
> > * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in supermarkets or
> > liquor stores
> >
> > * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
> > districts zoned for late night businesses.
> >
> > * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.
> >
> > Here are the email addresses of our local elected
> > officials:  <mailto:Aaron.Peskin@sfgov.org>Aaron.Peskin@sfgov.org;
> > <mailto:Jake.McGoldrick@sfgov.gov>Jake.McGoldrick@sfgov.gov;

Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 76141 invoked from network); 4 Feb 2004 19:37:20 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [167.88.192.30]
X-Originating-Email: [nesound@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: nesound@hotmail.com
From: "Gavin Varitech" <nesound@hotmail.com>
To: innocentchild@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Wed, 04 Feb 2004 11:37:17 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY1-F1682AG1VeQAhN0000888a@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Feb 2004 19:37:18.0173 (UTC) FILETIME=[4C9F50D0:01C3EB56]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

>Exactly. Remember something - that blinky button the Pioneer is EVIL. It's 
>a
>handicap that shitty dj's who can't spin use to cover up their inabilities.

Wow! There's things I can show you. Just playing records to me is Evil. Now 
I prefer using the EFX500 with a mixer of my choice to the EFX on the DJM600 
(although the EFX500 does not have the DJM600's sample bank & looping 
capabilities) but given the choice of an MP44 with NO outboard effects 
processor and the 600 I'll take the Pioneer every time...

And NO, it has nothing to do with any hadicap and I'de like to think I'm not 
a shitty deejay. I handicap myself everytime I play by playing more records 
AND mixing longer than most jocks that I ever hear do (other than world 
class/ globe-trotting techno talent), my ass is ALWAYS out there on the 
line. All I do is take chances.
Despite the fact that I'm putting in much more work than the average deejay 
that I get to hear, it's still not enough. Still it's just playing records 
and that = borring! I can't scratch all that well so effects are naturaly 
the next step. And the EFX on the DJM's may not be the most versitle, but 
they are a lot better than nothing.

Now when you said...
>I could shoot any dj that thinks the flange effect needs to be on every 
>mix.

... I could not agree with you more. And yes, there are sh@tty deejays out 
there that do use them to mask thier trouble spots. However it always irks 
me when someone makes the statement that every time someone is using them is 
"cheating" or trying to mask something. You know, I heard some know-it-all 
wannabe superstar saying this about Stacey Pullen at the Transmat Tour in 
2000. And I heard the same type of kid say this about Misstress Barbara a 
couple years ago too. WTF, show me someone with the skill or talent as these 
two and I'll give you a dollar.

I think the key is, it is EVIL to RELY on effects. But it's also EVIL not to 
UTILIZE them if you can do it and do it well...

AUDi,
Gavin


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-Deejay Gavin Varitech
(916) 733-1615 - Bookings/info
(916) 412-3313 - Contact
www.techwesttribe.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

The problem is that the majority of people that insist on having a 600 abuse
the effects and can't use them well. I see that mixer as a toy and the
effects just as cheesey as those import cars with their stupid shopping cart
wings and ridiculous ground effects. Under the hood in both cases it's all
show with little go.

If Pioneer built that mixer to be a hell of a lot more solid and offered an
effects disable switch I'd be all for it. Of course I'd have that switch
mounted underneath the mixer and expoxied in an off position. =)

:: r ::

	charset="iso-8859-1"

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600 

Effex mixers seem to me to be kind of cheaply thrown together.

I would think a really high quality non effex mixer like a numark pro sm2 or
3, or something like that, with an additional effex controller would be a
much better investment.

all you really need is a 2-3 channel mixer, with high-mid-bass level
control, a good crossfader with adjustable slope (which is kind of a luxury
actually). I've had issues with the less expensive vestax faders, and
absolutely love the numark infinity faders. All the effex are fun but get
pretty played out and cheap sounding really quick.

I have a numark pro sm3, and it retails for about the same price as a
djm600. . . but without all the lil effex.

to me it's like winning a race with a naturally aspirated civic vs the guys
who kinda go the easy way and put turbos on everything. It costs about the
same but the base quality level is just so much higher.

thats prolly why experienced dj's love the Ranes so much, all your money
goes into actual quality instead of the lil bells n whistles. . .

: )

aK

I think both Behringer and Pioneer suck ass. My DJM 500 was a P.O.S. from
day one. The hardware on them is poorly built, and while it's very "user
friendly", it's just not worth the price tag. Either invest a huge chunk of
dough in a RANE, or invest little (but at least get something vaguely
durable) and get a Vestax.

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600 
Thread-Index: AcPrWXxIpV0czcKuR0SHBbXv0UJ/cQAAHtOw
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Feb 2004 20:12:24.0932 (UTC) FILETIME=[34593A40:01C3EB5B]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600 

I know I might get shot on here for saying this, but I just love my =
little 2 channel Vestax PCV-002 mixer. I love to mix long 2-3 minute =
transitions and the headphone pre-input fader allows me to keep the =
beats matched perfectly. When I was mixing on the DJM-600 I had to =
quickly get used to hitting a cue switch for the headphones which kept =
me going out of beat while I fixed the headphone level for the cue. To =
make up for this, I now only practice single track monitoring. It's like =
learning all over again.

As for effects: if you know how to use them properly, more power to you. =
As for me I would rather just make my own mix of a track in my studio =
where I have all the time in the world to apply effects to it, edit it, =
then burn it on CD, and play that live.

Osteen

-----Original Message-----
From: aK [mailto:aK@hard-grooves.com]
Sent: Wednesday, February 04, 2004 12:00 PM
To: DJBigDaddyG@aol.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER
DJM-600=20


Effex mixers seem to me to be kind of cheaply thrown together.

I would think a really high quality non effex mixer like a numark pro =
sm2 or
3, or something like that, with an additional effex controller would be =
a
much better investment.

all you really need is a 2-3 channel mixer, with high-mid-bass level
control, a good crossfader with adjustable slope (which is kind of a =
luxury
actually). I've had issues with the less expensive vestax faders, and
absolutely love the numark infinity faders. All the effex are fun but =
get
pretty played out and cheap sounding really quick.

I have a numark pro sm3, and it retails for about the same price as a
djm600. . . but without all the lil effex.

to me it's like winning a race with a naturally aspirated civic vs the =
guys
who kinda go the easy way and put turbos on everything. It costs about =
the
same but the base quality level is just so much higher.

thats prolly why experienced dj's love the Ranes so much, all your money
goes into actual quality instead of the lil bells n whistles. . .

: )

aK

to install that extra zip. much could be said the same about a solid mixer
with the addition of that extra zip of an outboard effects processor...

same but the base quality level is just so much higher.

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Feb 2004 20:20:23.0589 (UTC) FILETIME=[51A67D50:01C3EB5C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

I still want the now deleted Vestax PMC-25 (or the 250 as it's sometimes
called). It's a nifty little horizontally built mixer, with big honkin'
rotary EQ knobs, kill FADERS (instead of just kill switches, you can slowly
eliminate an entire channel). I don't know what about the mixer I like so
much, but it's rad, and it was never very pricy (maximum price tag of
$349.00)

Anyone wanna sell me one for cheap??? :)

M-
----- Original Message -----
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, February 04, 2004 3:12 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600


I know I might get shot on here for saying this, but I just love my little 2
channel Vestax PCV-002 mixer. I love to mix long 2-3 minute transitions and
the headphone pre-input fader allows me to keep the beats matched perfectly.
When I was mixing on the DJM-600 I had to quickly get used to hitting a cue
switch for the headphones which kept me going out of beat while I fixed the
headphone level for the cue. To make up for this, I now only practice single
track monitoring. It's like learning all over again.

As for effects: if you know how to use them properly, more power to you. As
for me I would rather just make my own mix of a track in my studio where I
have all the time in the world to apply effects to it, edit it, then burn it
on CD, and play that live.

Osteen

-----Original Message-----
From: aK [mailto:aK@hard-grooves.com]
Sent: Wednesday, February 04, 2004 12:00 PM
To: DJBigDaddyG@aol.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER
DJM-600


Effex mixers seem to me to be kind of cheaply thrown together.

I would think a really high quality non effex mixer like a numark pro sm2 or
3, or something like that, with an additional effex controller would be a
much better investment.

all you really need is a 2-3 channel mixer, with high-mid-bass level
control, a good crossfader with adjustable slope (which is kind of a luxury
actually). I've had issues with the less expensive vestax faders, and
absolutely love the numark infinity faders. All the effex are fun but get
pretty played out and cheap sounding really quick.

I have a numark pro sm3, and it retails for about the same price as a
djm600. . . but without all the lil effex.

to me it's like winning a race with a naturally aspirated civic vs the guys
who kinda go the easy way and put turbos on everything. It costs about the
same but the base quality level is just so much higher.

thats prolly why experienced dj's love the Ranes so much, all your money
goes into actual quality instead of the lil bells n whistles. . .

: )

aK

From sfraves-return-109970-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 04 22:06:31 2004

Message-ID: <20040204140149.Y19631@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] News: India has a lot to rave about

India: Delhi Has Lots To Rave About

URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v04/n215/a10.html
Newshawk: Herb
Webpage: http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/468900.cms
Pubdate: Sun, 01 Feb 2004
Source: Times of India, The (India)
Copyright: Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. 2004
Contact: toieditorial@timesgroup.com
Website: http://www.timesofindia.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/453
Author: Sachin Parashar

DELHI HAS LOTS TO RAVE ABOUT

Will a moon so bright ever arise again? Drink a cupful of wine and ask of
the sky.

I don't know where the palace gate of heaven is, Or even the year in
which tonight slips by .

NEW DELHI : A starry night with the wind still and the moon shining in all
its splendour.

About 800 people gyrating to music at 150 beats a second at a clandestine
location near the Delhi-Gurgaon border in southwest Delhi .

And before you know it, you are one among the crowd, dancing with your
arms in the air, as if nobody knew you.

Nobody does actually.

Welcome to the new-age, psychedelic nirvana or the rave parties where
almost nothing is taboo.

There is unbridled fun though.

Hundreds of people, from anywhere between 15 to 40 years old, high on
drugs like LSD, cocaine, Alprax, acid and marijuana.

Gone are the days when heroin and opium were considered "with it".

And gone are the days when cocaine was available at Rs 2,500-3,000 per
gram in these parties.

"In the last year or so cocaine has become the lifeblood of such
parties.

There is a feeling that you can't enjoy raves if you don't have cocaine
and people are willing to pay as much as Rs 7,000 for a gram," says a
director of an event management company which organises rave parties.

An acid shot now comes at Rs 3,000 and ecstasy pills anywhere between Rs
800 to Rs 1,500.

Another drug which is much in demand these days is Alprax, a mood
enhancer.

The PLUR ( peace, love, unity and respect ) factor, which was coined to
describe the ideal rave vibe, is now beginning to take Delhi by storm.

The parties, the invitations to which are mostly through SMS, web sites or
just by word of mouth, start only after midnight and continue till late in
the morning.

The frenzy of dancing is matched by the electronic dance music, commonly
called techno, which lulls the conscious mind even as it stimulates the
sub-conscious mind and body.
"Even though raves are mainly restricted in Delhi to farmhouses or big
hotels, people here seem to be taking to trance music in a big way.

Most of the young DJs now know how to play it," says Seema Gill, an
associate with a Goa-based DJ.

Naturally, raves are the playground of the rich and the famous.

The organisers, however, tend to disagree.

"There are close to 100 rave parties held during weekends in south Delhi
and Gurgaon.

It's not just models, fashion designers or members of rich industrialist
families now.

Young corporate executives are taking part in a big way," says the
director.

For young executives, raves are fast taking over as a break from their
otherwise dour, competitive lives.

"This is one place where I don't need to watch my back all the time.

I keep coming back not because I can't enjoy the music elsewhere, but
because of the positive energy of the people around me who are allowed to
have more fun here than they would be outside," says Manish Singh, a
manager with a finance company based in Connaught Place.

Concurs Shamita Sachdev, a college-goer, "There is almost a mystical
experience about the meaning of life and death here; an escape from the
world of imperfections.

It's a celebration of life to me."

Most ravers, however, deny the popular perception of these parties as sex
orgies or a place where predatory sexual behaviour is encouraged.

"I think the use of ecstasy which is linked with sexual abandon has
fuelled this perception.

There is nothing to suggest that there are random sexual acts in these
parties, at least not yet," says Sachdev.
Others like Singh, however, believe that fun in any form at the raves is
that keeps them going.

"There is nothing predictable about ravers except for the fact that they
all want to have fun.

What's wrong with it?

India: Delhi Has Lots To Rave About

--=20
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
=C2much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

> Behringer makes a nice business out of ripping off technology from their
> rivals and using it to build nearly identical products. I'd suggest
> going with neither: the Pioneer sucks to begin with, for reasons too
> numerous to list here. If you want a mixer that'll last you for more
> than a couple of years, go with Rane, Vestax, or A&H.
>
> And while I'm not too fond of Pioneer's mixers, I would definitely
> recommend their EFX-500 effects processor. Match that with a solid mixer
> that has an effects loop (the Rane MP44's is sweet) and you're set.

henry was exhausted when it came time to go back to work, but at least he didn't have a boss looking over his shoulder all of the time. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

Efx are nice, but I think they're entirely unneccessary. I say, get a solid
mixer, and leave the efx by the wayside. (unless you get something like an
Electrix analog filter). You should be able to make sort of your own efx
just by doing creative eq'ing. (IMHO)

M-

> rivals and using it to build nearly identical products. I'd suggest
> going with neither: the Pioneer sucks to begin with, for reasons too
> numerous to list here. If you want a mixer that'll last you for more
> than a couple of years, go with Rane, Vestax, or A&H.
>
> And while I'm not too fond of Pioneer's mixers, I would definitely
> recommend their EFX-500 effects processor. Match that with a solid mixer
> that has an effects loop (the Rane MP44's is sweet) and you're set.
>

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 04 Feb 2004 23:38:59.0166 (UTC) FILETIME=[0FE33FE0:01C3EB78]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] News: India has a lot to rave about

"
Hundreds of people, from anywhere between 15 to 40 years old, high on
drugs like LSD, cocaine, Alprax, acid and marijuana.

Gone are the days when heroin and opium were considered "with it".

And gone are the days when cocaine was available at Rs 2,500-3,000 per
gram in these parties.

"In the last year or so cocaine has become the lifeblood of such
parties.
"

..this does nothing to help promote the acceptance of EMD among the
beauracrats, the powers that be, aka whatever you call them. As long as
people continue to describe EDM events as stomping grounds for "your drug of
choice", or a place for a random sexual act, you will continue to see the
opposition try and shut it down. I am disappointed not that there is an
emerging scene in India, that's rad (sorry "forever young" radiation still
pumping through me veins), but that the author had to spend the first half
of the article talking about the drug use, not the great music, or the vibe
that goes on. Wait, sorry, there was one comment about the atmosphere there.

Not everyone who enjoys EDM likes to end up in a puddle by the end of the
night and using this to describe an international/cultural emerging
sub-scene will surely not give those who have never experienced a rave, a
positive connotation about what goes on.

And Please, believe me, I am not trying to turn this into a "Jack's an
elitist" type of thing. "You" want to partake, fine, that is "Your" choice.
But, don't drag down the scene with "you", because "you're" associating with
it...that come out right?
--
DJ Jack Triumph

Jack,

	Your suggesting that talk of drug use is somehow a disservice or 
embarrassment to the rave scene likewise does nothing to help promote 
the acceptance of peaceful substance use among the bureaucrats or 
powers that be. Who are you to say that this goal is less valid and 
should have to take a back seat to yours in this community? Not 
everyone who enjoys getting high likes to damage his hearing listening 
to loud music at parties.

Groove on,
						<<< Starchild >>>

From: JBlaze112@aol.com

To: jacktriumph@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_197.253c58f0.2d52fba0_boundary"
X-Mailer: Thunderbird - Mac OS X sub 206
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] News: India has a lot to rave about

--part1_197.253c58f0.2d52fba0_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Well we know it's the journalist's job to tell the non-biased truth, and this 
article is full of the pro's and con's that come with the rave scene 
everywhere. Granted it might confuse the reader as to weather the article is supposed 
to be "pro rave" or is it trying to expose rave drug abuse and getting them 
shut down. The way I see it, the journalist is just telling the truth about the 
scene in India....   Say they had wrote this article and failed to mention 
that anybody used any kind of drug or mention drugs at all, THEN their senior 
editor went to India to a rave and to their suprise... noticed that lots of 
people were using LSD and cocaine and the likes. That reporter could lose their 
respect, and their job to another less biased more honest and controversial truth 
exposing reporter. Me personally, I find it inspiring to know that raves are 
coming on strong in India, and the extra fact that there are drugs going 
around the raves there too makes a difference in the way I image the story and 
what's happening over there. 
     I just don't think we can blame the journalists for writing a story, if 
we treat them like outsiders and act secretively towards them, they will look 
for what we're hidding (such and drugs, sex etc.) the way to get positive 
media is to impress them and show them a good time. It wasn't always that way... 
but eventually the media became impressed with rock & roll, the media became 
impressed with hip hop, the media became impressed with break dance. It's about 
time the media became impressed with raves, they will start to omit the drug 
scene when we SHOW them the real rave scene, show them something that 
compleately and utterly overshadows the drug scene, just like a rock & roll stage 
overshadows the drug use at concerts.   And then "underground" can simply just 
evolve into something else. Remember... the media is not the cops, the media is a 
powerful weapon that was created to protect us from the gonverment. It's the 
first amendment. A reporter is like a portable recording device that is limited 
by the average american's point of view, if you're well cultured and can 
translate spectrum to spectrum and the rave scene hasn't broken you from all touch 
with the average (yes and somewhat ignorant america), the media can certainly 
be on your side. 



In a message dated 2/4/04 3:46:59 PM, jacktriumph@hotmail.com writes:


> "
> Hundreds of people, from anywhere between 15 to 40 years old, high on
> drugs like LSD, cocaine, Alprax, acid and marijuana.
> 
> Gone are the days when heroin and opium were considered "with it".
> 
> And gone are the days when cocaine was available at Rs 2,500-3,000 per
> gram in these parties.
> 
> "In the last year or so cocaine has become the lifeblood of such
> parties.
> "
> 
> ..this does nothing to help promote the acceptance of EMD among the
> beauracrats, the powers that be, aka whatever you call them. As long as
> people continue to describe EDM events as stomping grounds for "your drug of
> choice", or a place for a random sexual act, you will continue to see the
> opposition try and shut it down. I am disappointed not that there is an
> emerging scene in India, that's rad (sorry "forever young" radiation still
> pumping through me veins), but that the author had to spend the first half
> of the article talking about the drug use, not the great music, or the vibe
> that goes on. Wait, sorry, there was one comment about the atmosphere there.
> 
> Not everyone who enjoys EDM likes to end up in a puddle by the end of the
> night and using this to describe an international/cultural emerging
> sub-scene will surely not give those who have never experienced a rave, a
> positive connotation about what goes on.
> 
> And Please, believe me, I am not trying to turn this into a "Jack's an
> elitist" type of thing. "You" want to partake, fine, that is "Your" choice.
> But, don't drag down the scene with "you", because "you're" associating with
> it...that come out right?
> --
> DJ Jack Triumph
> Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught
>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: email viruses. . .damn them

SCO is Santa Cruz Operation, a company who sells a unix operating system
(SCO Unix). They claim that code they own was illegally added the Linux
kernel (Linux is a free open source unix compatible operating system), and
are threatening to sue anyone who doesn't pay them a license fee. They've
sued a number of companies, including IBM (for several $billion). Most
people think the lawsuit is frivolous. Try
http://www.google.com/search?q=sco if you want to learn more.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

--0-306682739-1075967254=:64634
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Yeah I think your right on the money with that Shawn. I have a Rane MP 44 and an EFX 500 and I think its a great combo...... but I still don't really use the EFX all that much, just a little here and there.
 
Kevin James
 


shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net> wrote:
quoth DJBigDaddyG@aol.com:
> out of the 2 mixers witch one is better the pioneer one is like 600$
> more money but Behringer says they got more FX's then pioneer... i was
> looking to buy a new mixer and this is what i am thinking about they
> both look the same and i think they even play the same... i need some
> feed back please..

Behringer makes a nice business out of ripping off technology from their
rivals and using it to build nearly identical products. I'd suggest
going with neither: the Pioneer sucks to begin with, for reasons too
numerous to list here. If you want a mixer that'll last you for more
than a couple of years, go with Rane, Vestax, or A&H.

And while I'm not too fond of Pioneer's mixers, I would definitely
recommend their EFX-500 effects processor. Match that with a solid mixer
that has an effects loop (the Rane MP44's is sweet) and you're set.

Good luck,
-- 
shawn allen
mailto://shawn@alterior.net
phone://+1.415.577.3961
http://alterior.net
aim://shawnpallen

dude,
I'm STILL getting now like 6-8 emails a day to addresses for my hard-grooves
domain (that don't exist) like bill@hard-grooves.com,
steve@hard-grooves.com, in addition to actual email addy's I have set up. .
. they all have subjects like, TEST, HI, . . .other things. . .

I thought the mydoom virus only sent emails to emails in people's address
books n such, so like why are all these email addresses that I know don't
exist getting emails to them ?

I guess it should go away more or less after the specified dates for the
propogation of the virus.
none of the emails these were sent from were real emails either. . .

even tho this is all annoying as hell, some viruses are just pretty damn
cool the way people have them work. . .I've never had norton anti-virus, and
personal firewall work so hard before.

and here I was thinking it was somehow all Osby's fault. . .

: )

aK

--=====================_22697016==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

UK INTROS ANTI-RAVE THOUGHT CRIMES

UK authorities introduced new laws this week making it a criminal offence 
to go, or even prepare to go to a rave, within 24 hours of being stopped 
from visiting another one.

The government also amended their infamous 1994 Criminal Justice Act 
definition of 'rave', keeping the notorious 'repetitive beats' clause while 
reducing the number of partygoers from 100 to 20 and making indoor squat 
parties also illegal.  Indoor parties become raves only if the building is 
trespassed, while any outdoor party with more than 20 guests (including on 
private land) can now be classed as a rave.

Liberty spokesperson Barry Hugill condemned the new laws, including another 
stating that just two people can now constitute a 'public assembly': "This 
is totally unacceptable, it should only be a crime to commit a crime… The 
government is introducing constraints and no-go areas the like of which 
haven't existed since wartime."

http://www.hughesguides.com/Law/news.html



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is the 
merger of state and corporate power."
-Benito Mussolini

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

if anyone really needs to know ... well OK ... this is what i  found first we 
where talking about people that can draw cartoon look a like people ... oh OK 
... scratch that ... think of Mario from super Mario Bro.'s looking just like 
you in his outfit he all ways wears that is what we where talking about using 
the cartoon bodys and puting real peoples heads on them but in a cartoon 
way... 

Well, then the subject went to old school games from back in the days ... and 
out of the blue the Rubiks Cube was on the main subject. People where saying 
"i could never get the colors to match so I swapped the stickers," etc., and 
blah, blah....

well i am here to save your day at the office... :-) just do not let the boss 
see you.. or hell you can even play this online version of the Rubiks Cube at 
your house and i think there is a PDA versions of it for your Palm Os and 
Windows CE download at www.downloads.com 

but you want the damn game right now? and you are sick of reading this e-mail 
because all i am doing is going on and on about stupid crap that is very 
useless in the day to day life style ... well OK here it is... i will not force 
you guys to read any more :-)

has anyone noticed the popularity increase of the Atkins diet ?=20

Subway, Chili's, and some other places also have an "atkins approved" =
menu with various items.

Didn't mr atkins recently die ?=20
>From what I heard, he had large amounts of blockages in his arteries =
from high cholesterol, not to mention the fact that he wasn't really =
very old when he died.

some people are just dumb as fuck these days.

and also, I still here of women going on hormone replacement therapy. . =
.=20
Studies have proved that estrogen replacement and such actually greatly =
increase the risk of a woman developing various cancers including breast =
cancer. . .=20

and infomercials,=20
Ronco has almost an exact copy of the infomercial for those Knife sets =
that have been popular for years. . . (copycat)
Susanne Summers sells some excersize machine with some Mitch Gaylord =
guy, but neither of them know what they're talking about, and neither =
are in any sort of shape to be promoting excersize machines.=20

btw, when someone refers to "cardio", is it reference to =
cardiopulmonary, or cardiovascular ?

I think television these days is one of the signs that the world is =
going to end soon. . .=20

it was obvious about when saturday mornings stopped showing all the =
cartoons. . .

What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is better ? Behringer DJX 700 or PIONEER DJM-600

If you don't care about effects. get the Rane TTM-56.  It's cheaper
than the djm-909, will sound MUCH better, and tons more reliable.  Check
out the cola test on the product's web page (http://www.rane.com/ttm56.html)
They imerse the crossfader in a bowl of cola.  Then cut with it while it's
still in the cola and it all works!  This mixer is the god of two chanel
mixers.

-Erik

-- 
What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] OK.. so i heard a Rumor....

-------------------------------1076096503
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hey, i lived through the 80s fer shurr ...  Whatever all a'you are going 
through in your 20s or so, I went through in the 80s. But you know what sucked? 
There weren't any raves then!  yeah there were clubs but they sucked as bad then 
as they do now. I have good memories of going out dancing but they don't hold 
a candle to the raves/parties I've been to since 1998, when i started raving. 
There was some cool synth-based "modern rock" and "new romantic" music. Stuff 
like Kraftwerk... yeah! ...Alphaville ... Yaz ...   even pop stuff like A-Ha 
was awesome (and gets remade into trance records). 
I was subscribing to a DJ newsletter back then and got some cool records as a 
result. I was playing Derrick May/Mayday in 1986 and telling people "this new 
house music thing is pretty cool!" Also got Frankie Knuckles ... Oh, and 
damn, I've got nine remixes of Janet Jackson's "Control," from about the time 
Justin Timberlake was first born, and the only nipples he had seen were on his 
mom. 
Lots of other stuff about the 80s sucked really bad -- Like Ronald Reagan, 
for example. Overall, though, good memories.

-------------------------------1076096503--

What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of

What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

- Rush Limbaugh. October 5, 1995 show transcript.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] phttt phttt. . .nrr

hehe,

like since I was 15-ish, I really got into weight lifting, nutrition n stuff
like that. I had a GF that I kinda trained and now she's gone thru school
for physical therapy, massage therapy, and nutritional courses and such and
has some huge ass BF, and her herself turned out pretty friggin ripped.

Everythings really simple, theres no need to go on diets.
Any diet that has such a narrow view of things like only cutting out
carbohydrates will never really work.
Simple, complex carbohydrates, proteins, calories, fat.
All you really need to know,
protein builds muscle, simple carbohydrates (sugars) are quickly burned off,
complex carbohydrates (wheat pasta, grains) offer longer lasting energy.
Fat is just all badd.
The whole calorie thing doesn't really make sense. . . isn't a "calorie" a
unit of measurement for the amount of a particular fuel that is burned
(used) in order to create heat or fuel something so it can act ?
Basically tho, if you consume more than you use in a day, the excess gets
stored as fat. "Calories" are used first with things like simple
carbohydrates, and fat is typically stored energy.

it's absolutely necessary to excersize, if someone actually eats normally,
in order for them to lose weight.
If you increase your protein, your body will have what it needs to build
healthy muscle. But carbohydrates (simple and complex) are required for your
body to do it's job also.

If someone was to cut out cheese, dairy, fatty meats. . . they would no
doubt lose weight and if they excersized and fed their body properly they
would definately give their body what it needed to work how it was designed
to work.

You can't completely cut out fats either tho, there is a such thing as
someone getting very very sick from a lack of body fat, somewhere around
3-4%.

All these people talking about cutting out the carbs. . .do they have any
idea what they're talking about  ?
>From racing MX, I would eat a strict diet, and carbohydrates were a huge
part of that. If I didn't eat well, come sat or sunday, I wouldn't be able
to last the entire moto without fading back.
There were also issues with lactic acids building up in the forearms which
every rider deals with in their own ways.
Oatmeal, wheat pasta, wheat toast, grains, cereals. . . they're mainly
complex carbohydrates. And these dumbass diets are telling people that those
things are badd, and they should eat bacon, n cheese, n ham, n whatever. . .
anything with high amounts of fat is horrible for you. Fat gets burned off
last, and immediately stored in your body after you eat it until your other
calorie/carbohydrate stores are depleted.

actually, if you know HOW to eat, you can have huge control over your body,
how it looks, how it works. . .

diets simply do not work, and never will. they're not good for you, and even
tho some people might lose weight, it's not in a healthy correct way and the
diet ultimately does a great deal of damage in all sorts of ways.

I'm not in the best shape right now myself, there was a period where I was
pretty sick and I had to concentrate on helping my body heal, so I gained
some weight and lost a lil muscle. But it's all just temperary cuz I did it
all on purpose, and know how to undo it. I would drink the 2000 calorie
shakes and high protein shakes for a while so I could literally just gain
weight. There was a point where I started getting almost out of control
skinny. . .  at one point I was around 165, and my ideal weight is about 25
pounds more than that. My immune system was being compromised and I had to
fix that, so I could heal from the other illness. Now that I'm hell of a lot
better, I gotta just lose the stuff I purposely gained.
Diet effects your whole body. People need to learn how to eat to live.

simple. . .

: )

aK

SFMAD BENEFIT
FOR CHRIS HACKETT & the MADAGASCAR INSTITUTE (nyc)
Friday February 13th, 2004 SOMA ARTS: 934 Brannan St (SF) 9pm-5AM
<http://www.laughingsquid.org/sfmad/>http://www.laughingsquid.org/sfmad/

Beats:
Adam Ohana (An-Ten-Nae/GET FREAKY)
LORIN
Space Cowboys
Laird (HOUSE, BREAKS)
SHAPESHIFTER (Seattle SpaceVirgins/ Drum &Bass, Breaksk)
Robb Rayle (Koinonea/CEIBA, Trance, Downtempo)


ON STAGE:
Attaboy & Burke
the Phenomenauts
Mongoloid
Beanweevils
Kid Beyond~Master Beatboxer
Mixtape From Mars
The Mobb
Monsieur Pheonix
Film and performance by:
Survival Research Laboratories (SRL)
Seemen & Cyclecide Bicycle Rodeo

Special Presentation by Madagascar Institute artists (straight outta Brooklyn).
Master of Ceremony: $teven Ra$pa
Rockstar Bartending: Flash and Family
Visuals by: Sunit
Mistress Levine?s Silent Auction
Altar to our Lady of Preventable Accidents
***Special appearances to be announced
__________________________________________________________________________
On Saturday January 24, Chris Hackett, Founder of the Madagascar Institute 
in Brooklyn, New York, sustained massive physical injuries when an 
art-piece he was developing detonated in his face. The explosion left him 
with broken bones in his face, a broken jaw, and burns throughout his body. 
To make matters worse, the accident led to a Joint Terrorism Task Force 
search of the shop and Hackett'sapartment on the top floor of the building. 
The police claimed they had found a weapon's cache and maps of major 
landmarks in New York. The NYPD confiscated all of The Institute's 
computers, maps of various spots in New York City, and other personal and 
professional materials. Like many working artists, Hackett has no medical 
insurance and no money to pay for the reconstructive surgery he will need 
for his face. Hackett's only asset is the home of the Madagascar Institute, 
a shop shared by more than 50 artists, based in Gowanus, Brooklyn.

The Madagascar Institute is a seminal arts organization in New York City. 
The Institute's artists have spearheaded dozens of street performances and 
events both in New York and around the world. Including: Glastonbury 
Festival in England, Robodoc in Rotterdam, and have been a regular presence 
at the Burning Man festival. In addition to staging performances and 
creating art, The Madagascar Institute holds both free and inexpensive 
classes on everything from sewing, to welding and auto-repair. People from 
all over New York's many diverse communities are drawn to The Madagascar 
Institute. The Institute has helped shape these individuals into skilled 
artists, welders, and machinists and many of these artisans have in-turn 
moved-on to create their own projects and art throughout the country.

The Madagascar Institute has been able to harness the energy of artists 
throughout New York, spreading the message that spontaneous art is 
possible. The police raid of the Institute and Hackett's apartment calls 
attention to tenuous rights of artists in this political climate. Anything 
that can be considered subversive could be linked to terrorist activity, 
and there are very few ways we can defend against this. Many of us are 
susceptible to surveillance under the Homeland Security Act, and some have 
already experienced other problems, like restricted access to performance 
spaces. We must support the civil rights of artists.

Volunteers: Laurie Schoeman: sfmadbenefit@yahoo.com Nina Alter, Media/PR: 
nina@bigwheel.net




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is the 
merger of state and corporate power."
-Benito Mussolini

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Friday, February 6, 2004 ** *Oneiromancy* presented by Oneiromancy **

ee of charge. We are working on the lineup, but as with all our events, we =
want to extend a special invite to all the new DJs who have never played an=
 event. We are setting aside a number of timeslots, in various genres, so i=
f you are dying to get out there to play, email me at wavelength_sf@yahoo.c=
om, with the subject "Oneiromancy" Be sure to include contact info, links t=
o demos (if you have one), and genre. I know everyone plays every genre, bu=
t if you could limit it to one, that would help. I'm going to randomly draw=
 names to play for each genre, so DJs who play a genre that is under-repres=
ented will have a better shot. Its all random: I dont care if we are friend=
s, enemies, whatever. I'll post the list the day after christmas, so thats =
the deadline. Oh yes, and unlike other times, hardcore DJs will definatly g=
et slots at this party. Hope to see you guys there. (look for the full line=
up the day after christmas. ) More info TBA.

Friday, February 6, 2004 ** Raigambre & Slowrider **

Leftlane presents

A special night of Latin Hip Hop Funk & Soul

Performing live:

Raigambre & Slowrider

on the wheels of steel - Mr. E (Dajoin, SF)

in the lounge: (spinning hip hop & r&b)

Frank"Muisc Man" Nitty
& Epik (Verbatum, SF)

Raiagambre || Bio

RAIGAMBRE (rye-g=E3m-bre) - roots, stability, tradition

"Raigambre's Latin-funk fiesta is one of the best musical bets around town.=
" -Chris Macias, Sacramento Bee, Friday, October 10, 2003
This group of talented musicians has been in the Sacramento music scene in =
various forms (Los Gallos, Motivo, etc.) for quite some time now. However, =
since May of 2001 they have come together under the name Raigambre. They bl=
end several different musical genres such as salsa, Afro-Cuban rhythms, fun=
k, and Chicano Groove. Another unique quality of Raigambre is the represent=
ation within the group. Members come from various backgrounds such as Mexic=
an-American, Native-American, and Caucasian.

If someone were to ask what Raigambre's message and purpose is, your averag=
e listener and fan would answer "dancing and a whole lot of energy!" While =
that may be true, Raigambre's songs contain very deep and serious messages.=
 "Caradura" (Hard Face) is a song that describes the expression on the Azte=
c people=92s faces as they fought to keep their land. "Se=F1or Ignacio" (Mr=
=2E Ignacio), a Cumbia-driven song, depicts a tale of a migrant farm worker=
 who has cancer yet still works hard to feed his family regardless of his i=
llness and low wages.

According to Chris Macias, Sacramento Bee Pop Music Writer, "Raigambre is s=
haking up Sacramento=92s nightspots with its earthy grooves and musical che=
mistry." In addition to being nominated for a SAMMIE (Sacramento Area Music=
 Award) in 2002 and again in 2003 for best Latin music group, Raigambre has=
 appeared on the Tony Tecate Show on KSFM 102.5 and MTV=92s Sorority Life, =
as well as playing in numerous festivals such as Festival De La Familia (Sa=
c.CA), Heritage Fest (Sac.CA), Picnic Day & Earth Day (Davis, CA.) and KSFM=
=92s Cinco De Mayo Fest (Sac.CA).

"Raigambre=92s biggest strength is that the band possesses a clear sense of=
 its own sound; it knows exactly what it should sound like, and that gives =
the music a sense of self-assurance," says Sacramento News & Review=92s Chr=
istian Kiefer. With influences such as WAR, Poncho Sanchez, and their own b=
lend of "Afro-Cuban, Chicano groove", Raigambre brings back to the music sc=
ene the tradition of deep rooted music.

For all the 411 check-out: www.bigfloor.com
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1092
Sacramento California, USA

ason Donald, and much more to soon be announced. These DJ's will pump your =
head full of funky beats through our recently upgraded crystal clear sound =
system. Special guest performers will provide live accompaniment to further=
 enhance your listening and dancing experience, details to be released soon=
=2E The venue we have chosen for this party is Tower Park Night Club, a bea=
utiful establishment on the edge of the serene delta, just outside of Lodi.=
 Tower Park Night Club over looks the river, has 2 bars, a large dance floo=
r, a smoking balcony over the water, plenty of seating/standing room, outst=
anding service, reasonably priced drinks, and clean bathrooms. The bar will=
 also be offering different drink specials throughout the night. Club PLUR =
Productions organizes parties that always have good vibes, friendly people,=
 a helpful staff and security, and excellent music. So come with good vibes=
 and be ready to have a great time. Wether you like to dance, drink, chill,=

r know who you might meet. This party will continue on the first Saturday o=
f every month through summer! The cover charge to get in is only $4. PLUS F=

Fresno area California, USA

Thursday, February 12, 2004 ** Gene Farris @ The Lotus Lounge **

Gene Farris | BIO

Gene Farris is the sinister minister of dance music=B9s changing sounds. Fa=
rris=B9s global DJ track record and extensive discography of over forty pro=
ductions are definitely a testament to the true Chicago house sound. Farris=
's unique dexterous DJ style that includes extended sultry, melodic blends =
with tuff beats makes him a party favorite around the world. House music is=
 Farris's undoubted passion that also drives his full flavored, colorful st=
udio creations. Farris's deep roots in house music and strive to be the bes=
t keeps him on the global electronic music industry's cutting edge.


Pushed by local kids in his South Side neighborhood of Chicago Gene Farris =
caught the DJ bug at the tender age of twelve. Inspired by the likes of Ron=
 Hardy, Prince, and Roy Ayers Farris began blending a mixture of funk, disc=
o, and soul combined with eighties' pop icons such as, Duran Duran. One may=
 still hear hints of disco in his style.


Even in his early years Farris was constantly on the move. By making mix ta=
pes for his neighborhood buddies and selling them at many famed Windy City =
record stores like Gramaphone, Farris's spinning skills quickly developed. =
Not only did Farris's style evolve, his reputation rapidly grew. After many=
 late nights 'beatn' down neighborhood block parties, Farris earned his chi=
ldhood dream slot warming up for legendary Ron Hardy and Ron Carrol at the =
epic AKA Club.


As the early nineties approached, Gene Farris became a major player in the =
thriving Chicago dance scene. Wanting to hear more diverse house music Farr=
is inevitably began to produce his own tracks. His first production style w=
as tuff, loopy and tracky House. At the time Cajmere (of Green Velvet) just=
 started a new label named, Relief Records. Close friend, Ron Trent, urged =
Farris take his hard hitting tunes to Relief Records. Trent thought Farris'=
s tracky sound was perfect for the early Relief.


House music history was made when Farris took his demo to Relief Records. H=
anging out in the Relief office was another young Chicago DJ called Sneak, =
who also just made his first demo. Farris and Sneak both had their tracks s=
igned. The "Farris Wheel" EP was Farris=B9s debut release for Relief in 199=
4. Gene Farris, alongside like minded musicians such as DJ Sneak, Paul John=
son, Derrick Carter, DJ Rush, Ron Trent, Boo Williams and Glen Underground =
formed the new wave of notorious, soon to be globe trotting Chicago DJs and=
 producers.


The "Farris Wheel" EP was the beginning of a prolific production career. Ge=
ne Farris=B9s discography highlights works released on dance music=B9s most=
 respected labels such as, Defected/Fluential, Soma Records, Siesta Music, =
Force Inc., Formaldehyde, 83 West/ Camouflage, Communique, Defmix, Static, =
and more.


Being a leader in the industry, Gene Farris started his own label, Farris W=
heel Recordings, Inc. in 1998, with "The Copa Cabana" EP. Among the label=
=B9s many loved EPs is FWR 008 "The Spirit" - Gene Farris featuring Sneak r=
emix. In February of 2001, Gene Farris unveiled Farris Wheel Recordings's s=
pin-off, Farris Wheel Limited. Farris's concept for the new imprint is to s=
teer away from saturated samples and feature more original, organic product=
ions. Farris Wheel Limited artists are incorporating live feeds into their =
melodic soulful beats. Also, 2003 will see the release of the Farris Wheel =
imprint's first CD compilation of the its own catalouge mixed by Gene Farri=
s.


Currently, Farris continues his travels around the globe DJing for his fans=
 throughout the United States, Canada, and many European countries like Cro=
atia, Holland, Israel, and Russia. However, Farris still finds time in his =
busy schedule to devote in the studio. He is is working on a full length al=
bum of original music for release in 2003. Farris's motive for the album is=
 to push beyond the barriers of the current house music sound. Farris alrea=
dy collaborated with many remarkable dance musicians such as renowned house=
 vocalist, Robert Owens and a fresh New York City production favorite, Onio=
nz (just to name a few).
When asked about his future in music Gene Farris passionately replies, "Hou=
se music is my one and only true love. I've been with her for over sixteen =
years and never plan on leaving. She's my peace... me and the music."


As the critics continually applaud his greatening accomplishments, Gene Far=
ris and his Farris Wheel Recordings empire continue to thrive.


The international demand for the elite Chicago House sound has kept Gene Fa=
rris busy gigging around the globe for over the past ten years. Then Februa=
ry 2003 saw the release of Gene's "Textures" mix CD and 6-track vinyl, acco=
mpanied by his "Textures" world tour, and features and reviews in Jockey Sl=
ut, Muzik, Mixmag, Seven Update, Mojo, DJ, IDJ, Blues & Soul, Echo, Muzik.c=
om, Xpander.nl, Burn It Blue, Worlddj.com and many more.


"Textures is a tasty affair, lots of layers, lots of passion, lots of origi=
nality. Deep, sexy, organic house music with that essential Chicago touch. =
A collection to inspire...5/5" DJ Mag
"The first collection from respected Chicago producer Gene Farris' Farris W=
heel Ltd...As good a house mix as you are gonna hear this month...4/5" IDJ =
Mag
"It's deep jazzy, stylish, sexy and soulful, showcasing fast rising talents=
 in the Farris Wheel Family such as Roomsa, Audiowhores, Greenkeepers, Behi=
nd the Groove and Boo Williams. It's damn fine house, nothing too heavy, ju=
st good party tunes from funk to disco and jazz to soul, it's all here as G=
ene graces us with some proper musical music." www.4clubbers.net

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1076

Reclaim The Streets!

=A0 =A0

Posts: 3

Re: Reclaim The Streets Party (FREE)
=AB Reply #1 on: Today at 3:27pm =BB=09 Quote  Modify  Remove
------------------------------------------------------------------------
This Reclaim The Streets event is being used in part to help bring together=
 the SF "activist" community, with the underground artist/performer communi=
ty, and the late night dance/music communities. =A0We all experience first =
hand the increasing intrusiveness of state repression. =A0Art, performance,=
 music, dance, these are the things that celebrate life and should be held =
up and revered in our society. Instead however, it is these very things tha=
t are constantly trying to be squashed. =A0If you want to have an art exhib=
ition, a performance, a concert, or a party, you have to jump through all s=
orts of bureaucratic hoops, pay for all sorts of permits, and then IF they =
approve of things, you are allowed to have your event. What happens if you =
don't have the means to meet all of their ridiculous standards? What if you=
 don't have the money to pay for all of their permits? Your options include=
 not having the event at all, or having it anyway illegally. And so we have=
 these unpermitted events. Often. And almost as often we have them shut dow=
n by the police. Or they just come in and harass people. For what? For enjo=
ying life? For celebrating that which makes us human? But we're experiencin=
g it more and more. And now they have the RAVE act at their disposal too. A=
nd it is going to continue to get worse until we rise up and say "Enough!"
=A0
So that is part of what we're doing with this RTS. Showing that if you
won't let us have our events in our own spaces where we aren't bothering an=
yone, than we are going to take it to the streets and have our events there=
!
=A0
For more info about RTS itself, you should go straight to the source. These=
 two links are from the London RTS group which began RTS originally way bac=
k in the day. They're a bit long, but very worth reading.
http://rts.gn.apc.org/evol.htm
and
http://rts.gn.apc.org/prop01.htm
=A0
See You There!
http://www.rts-sf.org (still working on this)
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1078
San Francisco California, USA

e night vanished just before winter. Recently, we were told that Mirage wil=
l once again take shape in February. All who were involved with Mirage will=

Friday, February 27, 2004 ** Progression's New Night! With Guest's fLOORCRA=
fT & Marc(0) **

 pro=B7gres=B7sion n.
The process of progressing; progress.
Movement from one member of a continuous series to the next.
A continuous series; a sequence.

secured a new night, at the same location.

Our new monthly event will fall on the 4th Friday's of each month.

Same great resident's, all new guest dj's, and that consistent progressive =
napalm that you've come to enjoy, being dropped without hesitation. We are =
putting out a call for the masses to join our party, a temporal community w=
here an attitude of acceptance, comradery and freedom prevails. This is the=
 next chapter in our underground movement, with its roots founded on electr=
onic music and our personal desire to expose it to everyone.

The Guests
--
February 27th, 2004

Thursday, March 4, 2004 ** Breakthru presents DJ HYPER! **

Thursday, March 4th, 2004
Breakthru presents:

DJ HYPER [Bedrock, Kilowatt, Hope, UK]
DJ Hyper needs no introduction, but here's one anyway: With releases on Bed=
rock, Acetate, Hope Recordings, and his own imprint, Kilowatt Recordings, G=
uy Hatfield is no stranger to the breakbeat world. With 2 successful CDs on=
 Bedrock recordings, and a new CD set to be released, Hyper plans to storm =
the dancefloors as only he can. This event will be a CD release party for h=
im, as well as the official Crystal Method afterparty!


JONDI [MOMU, Bedrock Breaks, Looq Recs.]
Jondi Moyer along with Mark Musselman make up the recording duo MOMU. With =
several releases on different labels, they are juicing the progressive brea=
ks scene for all it's got. Mark and Jondi have recently been doing a live a=
ct with much success, and this night Jondi will be doing a special breaks s=
et for us!

A:DUBL [Breakthru Recordings]
Breakthru founder and label owner will be giving resident support. Be sure =
not to miss out!

Houseroom:
JEFFREY ALLEN [Fastvibes, LA]
HOJ [Looq Recs.]

-------------------------------------------------
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org


---------------------------------------------------------------------

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

This year Moksha Tribe is two years old and we're hoping you will join us 
for a very special party we are creating to celebrate our 
anniversary:  Catch 20-2.  Saturday, March 20th on the spring equinox.

2004 also marks the twentieth anniversary of the release of the first house 
recording, "On and On," so Moksha will be throwin' down the beats and the 
love to commemorate 20 years of EDM and 2 years of our underground 
family.   Catch 20-2 will feature four rooms of music, special guests and 
surprises,  and decorations and memories from all the parties we've thrown 
since Aboriginal.

The music, I guarantee, will be kick ass!!!! We will be sending out more 
info when we firm up the DJ selection.

Hope to see you on the dancefloor March 20th!!!

Much love,

Apollo for Moksha Tribe

are sluggs poisonous to kitties ?

jeez, like an hour or so ago, brian came in thru my window like he has =
for the past few years, but he was like foaming at the mouth. He had all =
this funky foamy slobber hanging out of his mouth, and there was this =
smell that I couldn't find till a lil bit later. I was all over the =
house trying to figure out what this smell was and where it was coming =
from then I went to brian and noticed that every time he opened his =
mouth I smelled this nasty smell. He was licking himself from several =
feet away and I could smell it. Like every time he opened his mouth it =
was like . . .well it wasn't pretty. He tried to lick me and I was like =
HELL NO. . .=20
He's doing okay right now, he ate some and drank some water.=20
All I could think of is maybe he ate a slugg. Like you know how a slugg =
gets all frothy if you pour salt on it, well that was how his mouth =
looked. He's acting normally so i'm thinking he's ok.
If I find out someone poisoned him I'll seriously be pissed off.=20

does anyone know if sluggs are poisonous to cats ? What about most local =
ordinary frogs ?=20
I guess it had to be something that gave him a fight or something, I =
couldn't imagine him wanting to eat a slugg, but it kinda smelled like a =
burnt slugg or something. I could see him chasing down a frogg and =
eating it tho (like for fun).

it all kinda made me think about what would happen if I lost him. . =
.it'd be pretty devastating. I never had a budd like him before.
We met one day a few years ago (he came to me), I was spinning in front =
of my room window and this strange cat climbed up and started scratching =
at my window. Ever since then he's spent every night watching over me =
and kinda just protecting me n keeping me company when I needed it. =
Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night and he's above me just =
watching me, then kinda gives me one of those grins where he squints his =
eyes. . .

I'm sure he'll be ok, but I was pretty worried there for a lil while. =
I'll have to watch him tonight and if he acts weird at all I'll take him =
to the kitty er.

while i'm on the subject, it's sad when I see people take their loved =
family members to the vet, and they have their budd "put down" cuz it's =
too expensive for them. I've seen that a bunch of times, if it was me in =
that situation I'd deal with the bills. . . like moneys insignificant =
when it comes to loved ones yknow.

but yeah,=20
thanks all

arycK

From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
Date: Sun, 8 Feb 2004 10:36:05 -0500

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC:  Support Later Last Call Hours

hmm ... well it looks like the SFLNC is finally doing something.  for  
months they've had the same stuff up there, and then that blurb about  
"we're reducing our staffing to 9 members ... oh, and by the way would  
you like to be one of those members?" tells me they don't even have 9  
people interested enough in keeping that thing going.  does anyone else  
notice that, or am i the only one?  well, whatever ... no one wants to  
talk about it, i know, they just want to blindly support the cause ...   
i'm just trying to be the devil's advocate here, whether or not *aunt  
leslie* approves of it ... or osby thinks i'm doing that *stuff* again  
...

but anyway ...

the big question is, how much like new orleans would parts of the city  
become?  everyone, and i mean everyone's drunk in the french quarter.   
is that good or bad?  the french quarter's nice, but i wouldn't want to  
live there.  know what i mean?  are we going to make every bar open  
till 4am, or just certain clubs that have a bar?

anyone have the statistics of drunk driving incidents per capita  
compared with a 2am city to a 4 or 6am city?  i would imagine it might  
go down because people could stay longer.  that's my only real concern  
about this legislation.  we may be evolved enough as a society to allow  
later hours.  europe is, but europeans are also generally taught  
moderation with alcohol from a very young age.  you have 19 year olds  
in pubs talking about philosophy in france, where in america, you have  
21 year olds drinking too much and the main focus is where to get a  
piece of ass.  so some of our problems can't be fixed by legislation,  
they have to be reinforced culturally.

this could be a good piece of legislation as long as san francisco  
adapts it to fit the needs of the city.

-d

>> <http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_index.asp>http://www.sfgov.org/ 
>> site/bdsu
>> pvrs_index.asp
