>> > Here are some important points about this proposal:
>> >
>> > * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world  
>> class city
>> >
>> > * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the city  
>> and
>> the
>> > state of California
>> >
>> > * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other  
>> major
>> cities
>> >
>> > * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later  
>> last call
>> > hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of  
>> alcohol
>> > related traffic fatalities.
>> >
>> > * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at  
>> restaurants,
>> bars,
>> > or nightclubs
>> >
>> > * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in  
>> supermarkets or
>> > liquor stores
>> >
>> > * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
>> > districts zoned for late night businesses.
>> >
>> > * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC:  Support Later Last Call Hours

DEEP !

whussup mann. . .

haven't heard from you in a long while. . .

yeah, I didn't want to say too much negative stuff about the sflnc in
public, but one of the main reasons why I drifted out was cuz of the
direction they were starting to go which differed greatly from what I felt
would have been much more "for the community".
Things were a lot more positive when they (we) were starting out. When there
was the sc meetings, and the gr meetings. Then a while after that things
started getting way too political in a badd kinda sellout way.
I don't mind talking about it, I just thought that some of my old buds were
still involved, but the guys like pete, deep, osby, angelica. . . you guys
were my favorites. The sflnc kinda just lost their way after about 2 years.
It was sad cuz there was a ton of potential, but I guess the temptation of
getting bigger and stronger, and having more money, etc just got to em.

I loved the things I was involved in, cuz I usually did my things my way in
a way. But after everything was becoming so regulated, people started
developing these attitudes that to me are just more rightfully in place like
20 years ago in the business industry, and not for a nighlife saving
organization with new age views. I raised mobs of money for toys for tots,
got people to bring in literally hundreds of toys n such. I was never
supposed to tell anyone this, but I thought it was a beautiful thing-
yknow Carl from the end-up. . .one year people didn't bring in all too many
toys for the tots programs and he went to toys r us and bought thousands of
dollars worth of toys. . .enuf to fill like 10 of those barrels plus some. I
always thought that was just awesome of him but he didn't want me to tell.
Fun stuff, positive stuff. He definately deserved some credit.

It's pretty wack to see how things are now. I'm glad I got out when I did,
before it started to turn me into someone i wouldn't like.

and leslie. . . well. . .I never liked how she seemed to try to hogg the
spotlight in ways. She seemed to try to take credit for things like those
bumperstickers we had that said "dancing is not a crime".
I still have a bunch of em btw. Originally a cool guy from ratkoonrat came
to me with his design and idea (he told me it was for a local radio show
promo idea thing), I went to postscript press and had them printed. . . Pete
payed for it. But I saw leslie saying she was responsible and heard other
people talk about those stickers saying like "oh you mean leslies stickers?"
.
I became tired of the fairy ravemother pretty quick, and not that she wasn't
a sweet person. . .she just went down the wrong path.

I personally think it would have been much more honorable for the sflnc to
actually fail and disband, then to turn the direction I've seen them going.
For a bunch of hipsters, it was suprising to see how they would have all
these strict guidlines about how they should look in the publics eye, act
with political officials and such. But then again I guess the real hipsters
ended up falling out along the line due to large differences in opinion.

Are there still any of the original sc members involved anymore ? I was
involved for a lil more than 2 years, and started about a month or so after
they originally got their idea. It was all much diffirent then, much better
I feel.

godd I wouldn't be suprised if they had lawyers ready to attack people like
me who were once involved and aren't afraid to speak their mind about their
lack of direction in public.

some of us should get together and start our own organization with like a
blood oath to never sell out, and to always stick with our own view despite
the political popularity opinion.

oh and deep, I had that invite for your list, but I responded too late. .
.send it to me again.

: )

take care all

arycK

> hmm ... well it looks like the SFLNC is finally doing something.  for
> months they've had the same stuff up there, and then that blurb about
> "we're reducing our staffing to 9 members ... oh, and by the way would
> you like to be one of those members?" tells me they don't even have 9
> people interested enough in keeping that thing going.  does anyone else
> notice that, or am i the only one?  well, whatever ... no one wants to
> talk about it, i know, they just want to blindly support the cause ...
> i'm just trying to be the devil's advocate here, whether or not *aunt
> leslie* approves of it ... or osby thinks i'm doing that *stuff* again
> ...
>
> but anyway ...
>
> the big question is, how much like new orleans would parts of the city
> become?  everyone, and i mean everyone's drunk in the french quarter.
> is that good or bad?  the french quarter's nice, but i wouldn't want to
> live there.  know what i mean?  are we going to make every bar open
> till 4am, or just certain clubs that have a bar?
>
> anyone have the statistics of drunk driving incidents per capita
> compared with a 2am city to a 4 or 6am city?  i would imagine it might
> go down because people could stay longer.  that's my only real concern
> about this legislation.  we may be evolved enough as a society to allow
> later hours.  europe is, but europeans are also generally taught
> moderation with alcohol from a very young age.  you have 19 year olds
> in pubs talking about philosophy in france, where in america, you have
> 21 year olds drinking too much and the main focus is where to get a
> piece of ass.  so some of our problems can't be fixed by legislation,
> they have to be reinforced culturally.
>
> this could be a good piece of legislation as long as san francisco
> adapts it to fit the needs of the city.
>
> -d

Subject: [sfraves] .: Dirtbox Radio Tonight | 2-charming crew : 2step/garage & DNB! :.


Tonight's Dirtbox Radio will be our first ever showcase of Garage, UKG,
and 2-step, with the 2-Charming crew representing to the fullest.  These
guys have rocked hard at parties in the area including Delivery & ALIAS,
so we expect no less of them this evening.  Peep the lineup, links, and
more info below:

Lineup (all times EST):
07-08pm - Ricky Ricardo
08-09pm - Brother Pinch
09-10pm - Light Touch
10-11pm - Joe Nice
11-12+am - ODJ & Jerel (drums and basses!)

Links:
128k - http://64.246.60.15:8800/listen.pls
64k - http://jungletrain.net/64kbps.pls
24k - http://jungletrain.net/24kbps.pls

webcam - http://glue.umd.edu/~odjallen/dirtboxradio/webcam.html

chatroom - http://jungletrain.net/index.php?page=2&subpage=0&color=2

For current info, upcoming lineups, archives, and all that good shit, go
to www.dirtboxradio.com.  Everything you could possibly need is there!

Biggup to the Blended crew and all the peeps that came out and supported
the Destroyer.net takeover @ Sonar on Wednesday.  Shit was a lot of fun,
and you missed out if you weren't there!

Aight I'm off to get food & beer.  See y'all in the chat or on IM:)

Jackson aka ODJ

Partners in Crime, www.DirtboxRadio.com, Trividual Productions, ALIAS

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

jane peered across the room, and saw henry with a dazed looked in his eyes. she could tell, damn it all, he was daydreaming again! 
henry knew that people thought he was totally self absorbed, but if they could only read his mind...... you see, henry was contemplating the physics of toilet bowl and toothbrush, and how was it that the toothbrush always seemed to make it into the toilet bowl, and the stuff that should be in there, didn't always quite make it in there, and consequently, was a source of tension between himself and his last live-in mate...:)

Subject: [sfraves] little love for lieb, last minute breaks and garage of mad wax

friday:
hit up "knees up" happy hour at vertigo bar.  drink some cheap drinks.  
really good music being layed down by the DJs who are also the owners of 
tweekin and BPM records in SF.  drink more cheap drinks.  must remember to 
come back to this place.
head to 1015 with homeys (including mike m.) with free passes in hand to 
check out oliver lieb.  place is pretty dead. hoping it fills up later.  it 
doesn't.  pound a redbull and vodka.  run into shelly.  oliver comes on.  
good shit.  room is pretty dead.  wander around to other rooms, basement is 
closed, front room has some booty music.  drink a beer.  place is pretty 
dead.  go back to oliver.  good shit.  place is pretty dead.  head home.

saturday:
barely wake up in time.  hungover and smell of alcohol.  book on over to 
berkeley to teach a taichi class.  wonder if the students can tell i'm 
hungover.
at night, decide to walk on over to 330 ritch for "last minute" breakbeat 
party.  meet up with aaron jae.  run into tamara.  drink affordable beer.  
see phillip.  dance to breaks.  drink more affordable beer.  talk to some 
folks.  not feeling the DJ (dunno his name) and head home.

sunday:
friend IMs me with info on some crazy record sale out of someone's garage in 
castro.  take muni.  spend several hours flipping through stacks and stacks 
of records (claims there were 20,000 records in there...and it's probably 
true).  $1 per record.  pick up tasty morsels including pebbles, trinere, 
ready for the world, the jets, jj fad, new edition.  walk home happy (had to 
walk because i spent all my money on records and didn't have muni fare).

the end.

must develop a product of some sort from beginning to end.  I am interseted in 
developing a product that would benefit DJ's in some way.  I rather do a DJ 
related project because I think it would make it more fun and interesting for me.

Are there any DJ products or accessories that currently out on the market 
that need some improvement or changes?

Are there any DJ products or accessories that you would like to see in order 
to make your life easier as a DJ?

webstie to help DJs or even a packaging concept of some sort.

***The National Electronic Dance Music Conference***

http://www.nedmc.com

  In Washington D.C. on September 3rd through 6th 2004, the National EDM =
Conference will take place at the Omni Shoreham Hotel. We will be =
utilizing the entire space of the hotel to bring you the best possible =
environment to network with others in the EDM industry. We will be =
hosting all genres, from hip hop to hardcore, from house to industrial. =
As well, we will also be showcasing the newest technologies for the =
coming year and beyond, as well as offering seminars and focus groups to =
help dj's, producers, and gear manufacturer's push the envelope of music =
production and presentation.

  We have chosen D.C. to host this event because it is a central =
location on the east coast, offering easy access from many spots around =
the country, as well as being home to one of the nations largest EDM =
focused communities. We will be working closely with all businesses =
involved to ensure top notch production on all sides for after hours =
events, as well as demonstrations of said products. There will be also =
attendee only events, so be sure to sign up early to gain access to =
these events, held exclusively in the hotel.

  We at the NEDMC pride ourselves on being a community oriented event. =
That is why we are asking your input on what types of seminars, panels, =
and other types of educational meetings. We have created an input form =
on our site for your convenience, and ask that you fill it out so that =
we may custom tailor our event to the industries needs. We could have =
simply placed seminars according to how we see things in the industry, =
but we would rather make this a community event, and want to know what =
you want to see. You can use the form at =
http://www.nedmc.com/seminarfdbk.html or simply send us an email at =
info@nedmc.com.

  To stay up to date on all the happenings of the NEDMC, including =
seminar information, hotel and registration discounts, and event =
information, please visit http://www.nedmc.com/contact.html

  For further information on either sponsoring, exhibiting, attending, =
or hosting an official event, please email info@nedmc.com , or visit our =
site at http://www.nedmc.com .

  If you would like to help out with the NEDMC, please e-mail =
info@nedmc.com for intern and volunteering opportunites.=20


http://www.nedmc.com
The National Electronic Dance Music Conference
P.O. Box 3616
Fairfax, VA 22038
O:703-503-1020
F:703-503-1269
info@nedmc.com

Subject: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers

Hey all.

I was just wondering what your sources were for rhythms in your projects?  
What do you use for synth sounds, atmospheric sounds, stuff like that?  I 
generally build my drums with Reason, sample a bunch of records, lay down 
the bass with reason(or my buddy lays down some bass guitar riffs).

I dunno..  I just haven't been extremely happy with Reason and sampling 
being my sole source for rhythms.  I play piano by ear, so I am seriously 
thinking of getting some kind of keyboard.  I already have a full sized, 
weighted, digital pianowith midi hook-ups...

Maybe I should head on over to Guitar Center and play around with some of 
their gear.  It's just that, a lot of my friends who produce tell me that 
software is the only way to go as far as getting atmospheric and ryhthmical 
sounds....

Thanks all!

fable....

Every Fourth Tuesday at 2-3 pm est Cobalt Radio will air showcasing a=20
different Cobalt recording artist  each month starting in march.  First show=
 will=20
include the co-owner of Cobalt Recordings Dj Pisces.  For updated informatio=
n on=20
Cobalt Radio log onto Gravy FM : www.gravyfm.net=20

DJ Pisces Bio:=20

       Born and raised in Detroit, DJ Pisces was constantly exposed to=20
electronic music.  From 80=E2=80=99s New Wave acts such as Missing Persons,=20
Blancmange, Simple Minds, and The The  to Chicago hip-house of Tyree Cooper=20
and Mr. Lee to early Detroit Techno of Juan Atkins and Underground=20
Resistance, his musical taste was defined and refined.

     While serving in the U.S. Army stationed in Germany, DJ Pisces again=20
received first-hand knowledge of the exploding electronic music scene by=20
attending legendary German clubs such as The Front, The Dorian Grey, and=20
Sven Vath=E2=80=99s Omen. After meeting several DJs, Pisces decided to purch=
ase a=20
mixer and two turntables in order to pursue DJing himself. Eventually he was=
=20
making more money DJing that what he was from the Army, this his decision to=
=20
leave the military to DJ professionally.

     DJ Pisces holds two weekly residencies in Chicago, and has played=20
alongside most of the Chicago local and international DJ talent.  His=20
flexibility as a DJ has allowed him to bring his unique style of house and=20
techno sets to clubs nationwide as well as Mexico and Canada.

     Not being satisfied with DJing, Pisces has turned his attention to=20
music production as well. DJ Pisces presently runs Cobalt Recordings with=20
co-founder Tony Russo and have remixes planned for release by artists as=20
diverse as Kevin Saunderson, Suzanne Vega, and Chris Rea.

     With 8 years of professional DJ experience, DJ Pisces is definately one=
=20
to watch.

Contact:
Timothy Dorsey
4128 N. Clarendon #206
Chicago, IL 60613
USA
Ph. 847-971-5928
Email - DJ_Pisces@Hotmail.com



Tony Russo
Cobalt Recordings
Co-owner
Bookings,Events, Promotions
e-mail : monk7923@aol.com


www.cobaltrecordings.tk=20

Thread-Topic: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers
Thread-Index: AcPvZKcOHLW3v7XARxGivsr1SXpS5QAAS2Tg
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 09 Feb 2004 23:53:26.0050 (UTC) FILETIME=[E8A80020:01C3EF67]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers

This is my normal work-flow these days:

1. Create main drum pattern in reason using tons of reasons effects
2. Create a percussion track in FruityLoops and add tons of effects
3. Bring both tracks into Sonar2 and sequence them
4. Go back and make a Bassline using either reason or fruity loops =
depending on the sound im looking for
5. Add the bass track to Sonar
6. Get cool samples and chop/cut them up in Acid and then bring that =
into Sonar
7. Add pads, lead, or arp with my XP-30 in Sonar
8. Mix down in sonar
9. Master in SoundForge
10. burn to disk

Depending on the project and my inspiration I can mix these steps up, =
but it gives you a general idea of what I think each program is best =
for.

Oh, and my songs would be very simple and crappy if I didn't have my =
keyboard to work out ideas on and to record pads off of. It's just too =
hard to try making good melodies and chord progressions with a human =
feel on softsynths.

Osteen

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 10 Feb 2004 00:14:01.0542 (UTC) FILETIME=[C9111E60:01C3EF6A]

Subject: RE: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers

This is hard to answer, what type of sound are you looking to obtain in =
your productions?

For myself, I enjoy nothing better then a breakdown with a warm pad full =
of emotions after a long looped out, progressive trance session with =
minimal melody or chords but lots of trippy effects (ex: Flash - closing =
session).
So I require a synth that has good pads (and Rolands and Korgs are best =
at that).

Do you require a weighted keyboard? 88 keys? Can you just make due with =
a cheap midi controller?

Maybe you need a analog modeling synth if you require something with =
tons of knobs to twist in order to get inspiration.

Go to the music store, bring headphones, and play for a few hours on all =
the different synths.

I personally believe that my hardware synth makes better quality sounds =
then all my softsynths, but that might just be the placebo effect.




-----Original Message-----
From: _ fable _ [mailto:fable4our@hotmail.com]
Sent: Monday, February 09, 2004 4:00 PM

Subject: RE: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers


What would you do if you had to replace your XP-30?  Would you get =
another=20
keyboard?  Get a sound module?  I need something mobile, since my =
digital=20
piano is not.  I guess the question I am trying to get at is...  What is =

more worth my money?  A keyboard, or a midi controller?

by the way...  I cant tell you how much I love working with sonar and=20
soundforge...whew!


>From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
>To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers
>Date: Mon, 9 Feb 2004 15:53:25 -0800
>
>This is my normal work-flow these days:
>
>1. Create main drum pattern in reason using tons of reasons effects
>2. Create a percussion track in FruityLoops and add tons of effects
>3. Bring both tracks into Sonar2 and sequence them
>4. Go back and make a Bassline using either reason or fruity loops=20
>depending on the sound im looking for
>5. Add the bass track to Sonar
>6. Get cool samples and chop/cut them up in Acid and then bring that =
into=20
>Sonar
>7. Add pads, lead, or arp with my XP-30 in Sonar
>8. Mix down in sonar
>9. Master in SoundForge
>10. burn to disk
>
>Depending on the project and my inspiration I can mix these steps up, =
but=20
>it gives you a general idea of what I think each program is best for.
>
>Oh, and my songs would be very simple and crappy if I didn't have my=20
>keyboard to work out ideas on and to record pads off of. It's just too =
hard=20
>to try making good melodies and chord progressions with a human feel on =

>softsynths.
>
>Osteen
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers



I really love Spectrasonic's "Stylus" for building breakbeat percussion.

Spectrasonic's "Atmosphere" is great for pads.

Everybody seems to love Reactor for synth stuff... but I still use
hardware.

The key is to get the hell away from Reason and onto something that
supports VST plugins... Orion can do this for cheap.  Otherwise, there
is Logic, Cubase, Sonar, ect.  There are hundreds of great VST 
noise-making plugins, many of which are free.

-troy

-------------------------------1076374611
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

gosh you guys have all the cool equipment ...   I do all of my tracks on 
Techno E-Jay on the PC   :) 

ok i admit it really isn't much more than a toy, as the reviews say. But it's 
a fun toy, and you can come up with cool-sounding (if unoriginal) tunes. It 
does have a lot of limitations, like you can't fade volume in and out (although 
you can adjust the volume of the entire track). But there is fun stuff you 
can do, like importing actual songs and adding things to them, and writing your 
own sequences. 
It's pretty good for real novices, and then if people really get into the 
idea of building tracks on the computer, they can graduate to something more 
professional. 
This isn't a sales promo ... I don't even know if they sell Techno E-Jay 
anymore, as I've noticed something newer and spiffier from the publisher 
(Voyetra).  I'm just trying to tell people that if Fruity Loops and so forth are over 
their head, they can take baby steps with something simpler and then move up.   
:)
It's a fun toy for after a party when you can't go to sleep but still have 
music in your head.
Jonnyr

-------------------------------1076374611--

From: Tim Hockin <thockin@hockin.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves]NRR: Q for Producers

On Mon, Feb 09, 2004 at 04:41:48PM -0800, Troy Sheets wrote:
> The key is to get the hell away from Reason and onto something that
> supports VST plugins... Orion can do this for cheap.  Otherwise, there
> is Logic, Cubase, Sonar, ect.  There are hundreds of great VST 
> noise-making plugins, many of which are free.

Don't forget FL Studio.  FL Studio was ranked the top Soft Studio over
Reason and Orion and Project5 by Computer Music mag.  It's a full VST/DX
host, with a ton of great features including slicing, looping, MIDI in and
out, audio recording, automation, etc.  It's stable and cheap as hell.  If
MIDI synths (external) are your gig, I'd go with something more traditional.
If you want to stay soft, you should at least give it a shot.  The demo is
downloadable, and can do everything but save projects.

The included samples kinda suck, but there are tonnnnnnnns of sample sites
all over the web to rectify that.

PC/Windows only.

http://www.flstudio.com

Get a palm pilot (I have a piece of turd PalmV).  There's a free BPM
counter app for those things where you just tap the beat in.  Fairly
accurate...

I'd say a Palm is one of the dopest things you can have for digging
records.  You can keep a "want list" of stuff you've heard in other
people's mixes or online or whatever, you can take notes, keep your
booking calendar, contacts, to do list, syncs with your computer so if it
gets lost you're not fukt, etc.

andyw

Na na na....Tap buttons arn't accurate enough, the mix would probably start sliping after 32 beats or so...besides, if "YODOG7" is designing something new, let's go for the gusto!  Check this out.  I'm talking something with a microphone.  Where all I would have to do is hold it up...press the "damn it I can't bpm match this F-ing track Button".....
and it would simply (Ha...probably not so simply) detect the bass hits from the monitors and tell me how fast the track is being played.  Kinda along the same principle as the BPM counter in the Pioneer DJM600 (ahh...what a great toy...oh I mean tool...who am I kidding....TOY!)  Wow after reviewing what I just wrote, I really feel like a cheater......oh well, it would be tight!
-Graham
Dj Gram (Synthesound, SF / Mach1, Sac)
synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com
http://www.freewebs.com/djgram 

AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

Get a palm pilot (I have a piece of turd PalmV). There's a free BPM
counter app for those things where you just tap the beat in. Fairly
accurate...

I'd say a Palm is one of the dopest things you can have for digging
records. You can keep a "want list" of stuff you've heard in other
people's mixes or online or whatever, you can take notes, keep your
booking calendar, contacts, to do list, syncs with your computer so if it
gets lost you're not fukt, etc.

andyw

Announcement & Call for ENTRIES:

MIGHTY MULTIMEDIA MONDAYS.

The Long awaited MIGHTY MULTIMEDIA MONDAYS will start
in March 2004.
The shows will be held at MIGHTY at 119 UTAH St in San
Francisco at 15th street. (I block from Dolby HQ on
Potrero).

Featuring the best, most interesting & out-there
Video, Multimedia, VJ/AV performance & other `hard to
categorize but easy to enjoy' Visual, Audio &
Performance media..

We will be featuring screenings of Experimental Film,
Animation, VJ art & other electronic visual forms from
all over the world, as well as Performances, exhibits,
installations & Funky Exotic music from the cultural
frontlines….

Among the shows currently in the works are screenings
of the best renegade video & film from London, NYC &
Los Angeles, as well as special presentations of short
pieces from some of the great talent working at S.F.
Bay Area FX, Animation & Post Houses.
We will also be featuring guest performances from
leading VJs, DJs, Musical & Visual performers from all
across the cultural spectrum.

MIGHTY is a NightClub/Gallery that features a
multi-channel Multi-screen in-house video system, a
lovingly restored Richard Long Sound System & a 21st
Century perspective…
We want the whole community to enjoy these
entertaining nights out - So we are keeping admission
at $3 (No-One Turned away for lack of funds)
Each show will run from 6pm until late & will be
`Looped' for `Happy Hour', Evening & Night Crowds- so
you can arrive any time & not miss anything.

We are currently accepting entries, demos & proposals
from VJs, Animators, Video & Film Makers, Installation
Creators, Performers, Lightartists/Designers & other
`Visualists'  - We are very open minded in our
curatorial attitude - We  & our audience are looking
for Depth, Creativity & especially forms & content
that are unique & original (or at least entertaining!)
- Basically, we want to be surprised by meaningful
works that we haven't seen anything like before..
  Preference will be given to well-paced content that
respects an intelligent, tech savvy audience.
We are committed to publicizing & promoting the
artists, VJs etc that participate.

Send Entries, Proposals, Demos etc to:
MIGHTY MULTIMEDIA
Stefan G.
971 Brussels,
San Francisco
California
94134
USA

Or stefango@yahoo.com

MIGHTY MULTIMEDIA MONDAYS in MARCH - MIGHTY 119 UTAH,
SF - (at 15th) 6 pm- LATE - March 1st, 8th, 15th, 22nd
& 29th - Admission $3.00




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is the 
merger of state and corporate power."
-Benito Mussolini

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Hello all.  I haven't posted in a while...and here I am posting some non "rave" event, but what the fuck does rave mean anymore anyway? 

 

OK, so Bondage-A-Go-Go is this Wednesday night the 11th at their new location, 

The Glas Kat on 4th street.  (the old Trocadero – anyone remember the Trocadero?)  

It’s their typical music: goth, industrial and 80s dance.  

AND this week there is a Bettie Page look-a-like contest.  Somewhere around midnight.  My girlfriend Esperanza won last year and is out to try again.  So I am just here to say if you got nowheres to go, go here and vote for whoever you think best, just make sure it’s her.

 

And before the club, there is a film about Bettie at the Roxy.

 

San Francisco Independent Film Festival

 

Roxie Cinema, 3117 16th Street at Valencia

BETTIE PAGE - DARK ANGEL

Wednesday February 11 at 9:30pm
Nico B.
2004, USA, 80 minutes
www.bettiepagedarkangel.com
World Premiere

The impact of Bettie Page on modern culture is undeniable and pervasive. If you’ve never encountered the saucy Ms. Page, this is a perfect introduction. And, if you’ve already joined the Cult of Bettie, you’ll relish this dramatic biography-narrated by Bettie Page herself. 

In the 1950s, the infamous Irving Klaw was a businessman who sold photos of movie stars. He quickly noticed his best sellers were pictures of tied-up women from Hollywood films. When the demand exceeded supply, Klaw produced bondage photos and films himself: A genre, and a star were born. 

Bettie Page was a sweet young Tennessee girl who had graced the pages of a new magazine called Playboy. Her striking features, knot-tying prowess, great hair and charisma-to-burn earned her the nickname “Dark Angel.” Although her films contain almost nothing that modern audiences would consider sex-just “sexy” dancing, spanking and girls pretending they can’t escape-they were absolutely scandalous 50 years ago. To avoid offending his customers, who simply desired Betty Grable, Marlene Dietrich or Johnny Weismuller in a loincloth, Klaw kept them (literally) under the counter, but that wasn’t enough. 

The ultra-low budget ($40,000) debut from underground filmmaker Nico B. illustrates Betty’s early career and Klaw’s inevitable encounter with the righteous forces of morality, and recreates some of Bettie’s bondage films. After Wednesday’s premiere join us at Bondage A Go-Go and see Bettie’s influence firsthand at their annual Bettie Page look a like contest.

-Bruce Fletcher

In attendance: Director Nico B.

Subject: [sfraves] free hip-hop CD's from Boomerang  (bsp)

Six songs.  Most of them are old raps with the lyrics
tightened up, new samples, and more practice on the
mic. A couple of new songs.  Vocals recorded straight
through, non-stop (2X for phattening.)

House culture, psychedelia, puffing ganja in the chill
room, disdain for pedestrian establishment, fart
jokes, fraudulent honky boasts, and a stupid story at
the end...  same old boomerang shit you grew up with,
slightly improved.

If you want a copy (even if you need to update an
older CD), send me your mailing address.  Don't be
shy, homeslice.  3-4 weeks shipping.  Track listing:


1.  The Birthmark....lyrics: boomerang
    Beats:  “Sandsteppin” by Martin Brew
	   Samples:  Lil Kim, the Ramones, American History
X, Paul Newman (Cool Hand Luke), John Klemmer, MLK,
Danny Hoch.

2.	Sweet Booty....lyrics: boomerang
	  Beats:  “Lebanese Blonde” by Thievery Corp.
	  Samples:  the Beastie Boys, Pink Floyd, PacBell
operator, Rod McKuen

3.	Bug Powder Dust....lyrics: Justin Warfield,
revisited by boomerang
	  Beats: “D.D. Luxe” by Clutch Deluxe
	  Samples: Hunter S. Thompson (fear & loathing in las
vegas), William Burroughs, Beastie Boys, Timothy
Leary, the Doors, Aphex Twin, N.W.A., Justin Warfield,
Men at Work.   Respect to the elusive poet Justin
Warfield.

4.	Lost....lyrics: boomerang
	  Beats:  “Porcelain” by Moby
	  Samples added from:  Martin Luther King, Rosko

5.	Oaktown, Baby....lyrics: boomerang
	  Samples added from:  Here Are The Facts You
Requested, Akire,  L. Bill Miller, Kahlil.

6.	The Family (formerly 'Lollipop')	lyrics: boomerang
	  Beats:  “Oh How I Cry” by Brigid Boden and the Dust
Brothers.

7.	The Chicken & The Cow	- a story by boomerang. 
Music:  “Ghetto Bird” by Ice Cube.

	- All raps recorded straight through (2 takes) in one
session, January 19, 2004.
	- Scratching, sampling, and instrumental remixing by
Boomerang.
	- Rap lyrics © Boomerang/Peter Sandifer 1996-2003
except “Bug Powder Dust” © Justin Warfield.
	- Instrumentals and samples used without permission. 

	- Please support these artists and record labels.

>Date: Mon, 9 Feb 2004 17:12:25 -0800
>
>On Mon, Feb 09, 2004 at 04:41:48PM -0800, Troy Sheets wrote:
> > The key is to get the hell away from Reason and onto something that
> > supports VST plugins... Orion can do this for cheap.  Otherwise, there
> > is Logic, Cubase, Sonar, ect.  There are hundreds of great VST
> > noise-making plugins, many of which are free.
>
>Don't forget FL Studio.  FL Studio was ranked the top Soft Studio over
>Reason and Orion and Project5 by Computer Music mag.  It's a full VST/DX
>host, with a ton of great features including slicing, looping, MIDI in and
>out, audio recording, automation, etc.  It's stable and cheap as hell.  If
>MIDI synths (external) are your gig, I'd go with something more 
>traditional.
>If you want to stay soft, you should at least give it a shot.  The demo is
>downloadable, and can do everything but save projects.
>
>The included samples kinda suck, but there are tonnnnnnnns of sample sites
>all over the web to rectify that.
>
>PC/Windows only.
>
>http://www.flstudio.com
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

Dj Gram <synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com> wrote:
Na na na....Tap buttons arn't accurate enough, the mix would probably start sliping after 32 beats or so...besides, if "YODOG7" is designing something new, let's go for the gusto! Check this out. I'm talking something with a microphone. Where all I would have to do is hold it up...press the "damn it I can't bpm match this F-ing track Button".....
and it would simply (Ha...probably not so simply) detect the bass hits from the monitors and tell me how fast the track is being played. Kinda along the same principle as the BPM counter in the Pioneer DJM600 (ahh...what a great toy...oh I mean tool...who am I kidding....TOY!) Wow after reviewing what I just wrote, I really feel like a cheater......oh well, it would be tight!
-Graham
Dj Gram (Synthesound, SF / Mach1, Sac)
synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com
http://www.freewebs.com/djgram 

AndyW wrote:

Get a palm pilot (I have a piece of turd PalmV). There's a free BPM
counter app for those things where you just tap the beat in. Fairly
accurate...

I'd say a Palm is one of the dopest things you can have for digging
records. You can keep a "want list" of stuff you've heard in other
people's mixes or online or whatever, you can take notes, keep your
booking calendar, contacts, to do list, syncs with your computer so if it
gets lost you're not fukt, etc.

andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ATTN all DJ's ..Need help with DJ related school project...

I would have to agree not to rely on bpm counter while mixing.  the same record can return different bpm rates on different devices.

plus there are concepts like "swing" and "syncopation" that make mixing infinitely interesting.

train your brain to match beats.

just my opinion,
JOnas

p.s. Gram are you still looking for techo artists for mach 1?  if so, give me a holler in ALL CAPS if you want.

>I'd say a Palm is one of the dopest things you can have for digging
>records. You can keep a "want list" of stuff you've heard in other
>people's mixes or online or whatever, you can take notes, keep your
>booking calendar, contacts, to do list, syncs with your computer so if it
>gets lost you're not fukt, etc.
>
>andyw
>
>On Mon, 9 Feb 2004, Dj Gram wrote:
>-&e->
>-&e->A hand-held BPM counter would be nice.
>-&e->-G

Three problems:

If this is a BSP, please mark it as such.

Why would you send a BSP to a San Francisco raves mailing list for an event
in Charlotte?

SFR has a no cross posting rule, so if you really want to tell us about an
event in Charlotte, please take the time to send it individually to us.

Not trying to be a bitch, but I know I made a couple oops when I moved out
here due to not being a tech head and I was thankfully corrected by a couple
friends before everyone hated me.

-Andrew

oh for sure.  Honestly I dont even use the feature, I spend to much time trying to decided what I want to play next, I dont want to waste the time using the bpm counter.  But like I said it would be sick if there were something you could just hold up press a button and get a read out.
-G

jdemanon <yomommasabama@yahoo.com> wrote:
close enough for categorizing your music by bpms, i would think.
not so sure it's a good idea to rely on a "bmp" counter on your mixer to make sure your mixes are on.

.02



Dj Gram wrote:
Now THAT'S not accurate!!!!! Holy! Bmp's have decible points just like any other number if your bmp is not right on your mix will slip.
-G

jdemanon wrote:
or...

count 15 seconds worth of beats. multiply by 4. there's your BPMs




Dj Gram wrote:
Na na na....Tap buttons arn't accurate enough, the mix would probably start sliping after 32 beats or so...besides, if "YODOG7" is designing something new, let's go for the gusto! Check this out. I'm talking something with a microphone. Where all I would have to do is hold it up...press the "damn it I can't bpm match this F-ing track Button".....
and it would simply (Ha...probably not so simply) detect the bass hits from the monitors and tell me how fast the track is being played. Kinda along the same principle as the BPM counter in the Pioneer DJM600 (ahh...what a great toy...oh I mean tool...who am I kidding....TOY!) Wow after reviewing what I just wrote, I really feel like a cheater......oh well, it would be tight!
-Graham
Dj Gram (Synthesound, SF / Mach1, Sac)
synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com
http://www.freewebs.com/djgram 

AndyW wrote:

Get a palm pilot (I have a piece of turd PalmV). There's a free BPM
counter app for those things where you just tap the beat in. Fairly
accurate...

I'd say a Palm is one of the dopest things you can have for digging
records. You can keep a "want list" of stuff you've heard in other
people's mixes or online or whatever, you can take notes, keep your
booking calendar, contacts, to do list, syncs with your computer so if it
gets lost you're not fukt, etc.

andyw

jonas j robledo <djjonas@lycos.com> wrote:
I would have to agree not to rely on bpm counter while mixing. the same record can return different bpm rates on different devices.

plus there are concepts like "swing" and "syncopation" that make mixing infinitely interesting.

train your brain to match beats.

just my opinion,
JOnas

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Dj Gram <synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040210020401.97148.qmail@web41307.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0402102318090.15880-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ATTN all DJ's ..Need help with DJ related school
 project...


Beatmatching the kinds of beats a DJM-600 can keep track of is a parlor
trick you can pick up in a couple hours.  I've got some records that make
those things bug out seriously (50 no.... 190 no.... no... um... 75!
aiiieee).

And as for tap buttons not being accurate enough... there was a time when
the rhythm for music was kept by humans, basically tapping very hard using
sticks.  And to be honest, electronica was pretty boring till they figured
out how to bring some of that error and funk back.  That swing, that late
in the pocket funk is the backbone of good jungle, breaks and hip hop.  In
fact, it's the lack of swing in most trance that prompts many people to
describe it as "teutonic", "unfunky", "white" or even "boring".

While it's fairly easy to develop a product that can track percussive
impacts, determining the tempo from anything but a monotonous "thud thud
thud" in a known frequency range is a pretty serious design challenge.

andyw

p.s. Hint... for a prototype of your handheld device you could try gutting
a Numark Beatkeeper... those things must be cheap used now.  In fact...
THEY ARE!

http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=3702408857&category=4785

First off thanks for some of the feedback I have gotten.  I have gotten many 
ideas and suggestions. Many of these I told my teacher today.  The response I 
got from my teacher should try something in print or web, since the my major 
emphasis is Visual Communication.  It may take to much time for to develop a 
BPM counter, since I do not know how one is built.  So anything that could be 
done in print or web is the route I should be going.  So my next question is:

Is there anything graphic wise, whether print or web related, that could 
benefit DJs in some way or another?  Maybe a DJ resource pamplet or website (which 
is something my teacher suggested),instructional, tutorial manual, etc. I am 
pretty much out of ideas.

I rather do something related to DJ culture since I DJ for a hobby and enjoy 
it, but to not limit myself, I am open to other ideas or suggestions that are 
outside the DJ realm.  For example, someone from a previous semester made a 
informational pamphlet about the Palestinian/ Israeli war.  So maybe something 
that brings awareness that a lot of people do not know about.  
                                                                      thanks  
 

--part1_12f.3b51f6d1.2d5b362a_boundary--

Make your BPM counter, then you hook it up to a
monitor facing the DJ.
The monitor will display random pix of luscious,
nubile young women as long as the records are
BPM-synced-
If you stray off beat, the pic will morph towards a
hairy beastress!

Subject: [sfraves] Right to Dance group? (was: SFLNC: Support Later Last Call Hours)

Aryck,

	I fully hear you. My sense of the situation was very similar to yours,  
and I got out of the SFLNC for similar reasons.

	Reading your post, it occurs to me that perhaps the time is ripe for  
starting another group more focused on building a mass movement for the  
right to dance at the grassroots level.

	Perhaps something more along the lines of the bicycle group Critical  
Mass -- make the focus throwing renegade parties with a strong  
educational/political flavor that get people out in the streets. Do  
extravagent "Love Parade" type floats for Gay Pride, etc. Perhaps  
sponsor a ballot initiative. Don't sit down with establishment  
politicians until we have a whole bunch of people behind us.

	Anybody know if the name "Right To Dance" is being used these days? I  
bought the domain name RightToDance.org, and have been waiting for the  
opportunity to do something with it. What do you guys think?

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>

>>>>> The SFLNC needs your support for a proposal that could have huge
>>>> benefits
>>>>> for the entertainment scene in San Francisco.
>>>>>
>>>>> Supervisor Aaron Peskin has introduced a resolution encouraging
>>>> State
>>>>> Assemblymember Mark Leno to develop legislation that could extend
>>>> the last
>>>>> call for alcohol in bars, restaurants and nightclubs in  
>>>>> California's
>>>>> largest Cities.  This will give San Franciscans and visitors to our
>>>> City
>>>>> similar rights to those enjoyed in New York, Chicago, Miami, New
>>>> Orleans
>>>>> and other large cities that allow alcohol sales after 2am.  This
>>>> will also
>>>>> provide a much needed boost to our local entertainment scene and
>>>> economy.
>>>>>
>>>>> The SFLNC first introduced this resolution at the Entertainment
>>>> Commission,
>>>>> which voted unanimously to support it.  Please read the resolution
>>>>>
>>>> here:(<http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/
>>>> materials/040
>>>> 057.pdf>http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/
>>>> materials/04
>>>> 0057.pdf).
>>>>>
>>>>> In your email to our elected officials, it is crucial to include in
>>>> the
>>>>> subject line the words "Support Later Last Call Hours".

>>>> not
>>>>> always read every email but they do count those for and against an
>>>>> issue.  If you wish to contact your District Supervisor by phone or
>>>> fax,
>>>>> contact info is available at:
>>>>>
>>>> <http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_index.asp>http://www.sfgov.org/
>>>> site/bdsu
>>>> pvrs_index.asp
>>>>>
>>>>> Here are some important points about this proposal:
>>>>>
>>>>> * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world
>>>> class city
>>>>>
>>>>> * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the city
>>>> and
>>>> the
>>>>> state of California
>>>>>
>>>>> * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other
>>>> major
>>>> cities
>>>>>
>>>>> * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later
>>>> last call
>>>>> hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of
>>>> alcohol
>>>>> related traffic fatalities.
>>>>>
>>>>> * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at
>>>> restaurants,
>>>> bars,
>>>>> or nightclubs
>>>>>
>>>>> * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in
>>>> supermarkets or
>>>>> liquor stores
>>>>>
>>>>> * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
>>>>> districts zoned for late night businesses.
>>>>>
>>>>> * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.

	format=flowed

Personally I think that this idea is just plain silly. A) If there's  
any place that should be legally permitted to sell alcohol after 2AM  
it's stores not bars and this bill wouldn't augment that part of the  
law. After all, the reason stores stop selling alcohol at 2 isn't  
sensible, If I wanna drink at my house and run out of alcohol at 2:15AM  
why can't I go walk to the Safeway and get some more? 2AM is totally  
arbitrary. B) Since when is the regulation of alcohol sales a major  
focal point for the SFLNC? I mean, we basically established that  
alcohol is an acceptable means of recreation in the 30s and while  
working to allow people to stay drunk as late as they want is probably  
a good thing, it's something that the alcohol companies ought to press  
if they really it.  and Finally C) I think it'd be more effective to  
legislate that bars and clubs stop serving alcohol an hour and a half  
before closing rather then let them serve alcohol later -- I mean,  
sure, maybe it'll bring more money to those businesses but let Gavin  
Newsom worry about that -- the fact of the matter is that drunk driving  
is a dangerous problem, and even if this doesn't contribute to more  
drunk driving, I don't really see what it does but create a system  
where certain businesses are allowed to peddle alcohol after 2 whereas  
others are denied. This will hurt the bars that aren't zoned for  
late-night entertainment, and it'll encourage people who've been  
drinking at home and run out of alcohol after 2AM to get in their cars  
and head out to the nearest late-night spot, putting the lives of  
themselves and others at risk.

Josh

On Feb 8, 2004, at 7:36 AM, Deepfog wrote:

> hmm ... well it looks like the SFLNC is finally doing something.  for  
> months they've had the same stuff up there, and then that blurb about

> you like to be one of those members?" tells me they don't even have 9

> else notice that, or am i the only one?  well, whatever ... no one  
> wants to talk about it, i know, they just want to blindly support the  
> cause ...  i'm just trying to be the devil's advocate here, whether or  
> not *aunt leslie* approves of it ... or osby thinks i'm doing that  
> *stuff* again ...
>
> but anyway ...
>
> the big question is, how much like new orleans would parts of the city  
> become?  everyone, and i mean everyone's drunk in the french quarter.   
> is that good or bad?  the french quarter's nice, but i wouldn't want  
> to live there.  know what i mean?  are we going to make every bar open  
> till 4am, or just certain clubs that have a bar?
>
> anyone have the statistics of drunk driving incidents per capita  
> compared with a 2am city to a 4 or 6am city?  i would imagine it might  
> go down because people could stay longer.  that's my only real concern  
> about this legislation.  we may be evolved enough as a society to  
> allow later hours.  europe is, but europeans are also generally taught  
> moderation with alcohol from a very young age.  you have 19 year olds  
> in pubs talking about philosophy in france, where in america, you have  
> 21 year olds drinking too much and the main focus is where to get a  
> piece of ass.  so some of our problems can't be fixed by legislation,  
> they have to be reinforced culturally.
>
> this could be a good piece of legislation as long as san francisco  
> adapts it to fit the needs of the city.
>
> -d

>>> benefits

>>> >
>>> > Supervisor Aaron Peskin has introduced a resolution encouraging  
>>> State
>>> > Assemblymember Mark Leno to develop legislation that could extend  
>>> the last
>>> > call for alcohol in bars, restaurants and nightclubs in  
>>> California's
>>> > largest Cities.  This will give San Franciscans and visitors to  
>>> our City
>>> > similar rights to those enjoyed in New York, Chicago, Miami, New  
>>> Orleans
>>> > and other large cities that allow alcohol sales after 2am.  This  
>>> will also
>>> > provide a much needed boost to our local entertainment scene and

>>> >

>>> >

>>> 0057.pdf).

>>> >
>>> > Here are some important points about this proposal:
>>> >
>>> > * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world  
>>> class city
>>> >
>>> > * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the  
>>> city and
>>> the
>>> > state of California
>>> >
>>> > * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other  
>>> major
>>> cities
>>> >
>>> > * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later  
>>> last call
>>> > hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of  
>>> alcohol
>>> > related traffic fatalities.
>>> >
>>> > * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at  
>>> restaurants,
>>> bars,
>>> > or nightclubs
>>> >
>>> > * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in  
>>> supermarkets or
>>> > liquor stores
>>> >
>>> > * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
>>> > districts zoned for late night businesses.
>>> >
>>> > * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional work:

> >> later hours.  europe is, but europeans are also generally taught

> >>>>> WHAT:  1. Write an email in support of extending last call hours

> >>>> alcohol
> >>>>>               2. Come to the hearing at the Board of Supervisors

> >>>>>
> >>>> <http://sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_page.asp?id=13954>http://sfgov.org/
> >>>> site/bdsu
> >>>> pvrs_page.asp?id=13954
> >>>>>
> >>>>> WHERE:  City Services Committee of the Board of Supervisors, City
> >>>> Hall,
> >>>> Rm. 263
> >>>>>
> >>>>> The SFLNC needs your support for a proposal that could have huge
> >>>> benefits
> >>>>> for the entertainment scene in San Francisco.
> >>>>>
> >>>>> Supervisor Aaron Peskin has introduced a resolution encouraging
> >>>> State
> >>>>> Assemblymember Mark Leno to develop legislation that could extend
> >>>> the last
> >>>>> call for alcohol in bars, restaurants and nightclubs in
> >>>>> California's
> >>>>> largest Cities.  This will give San Franciscans and visitors to our
> >>>> City
> >>>>> similar rights to those enjoyed in New York, Chicago, Miami, New
> >>>> Orleans
> >>>>> and other large cities that allow alcohol sales after 2am.  This
> >>>> will also
> >>>>> provide a much needed boost to our local entertainment scene and
> >>>> economy.
> >>>>>
> >>>>> The SFLNC first introduced this resolution at the Entertainment
> >>>> Commission,
> >>>>> which voted unanimously to support it.  Please read the resolution
> >>>>>
> >>>> here:(<http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/
> >>>> materials/040
> >>>> 057.pdf>http://sfgov.org/site/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/committees/
> >>>> materials/04
> >>>> 0057.pdf).
> >>>>>
> >>>>> In your email to our elected officials, it is crucial to include in
> >>>> the
> >>>>> subject line the words "Support Later Last Call Hours".
> >>>> Supervisors do
> >>>> not
> >>>>> always read every email but they do count those for and against an
> >>>>> issue.  If you wish to contact your District Supervisor by phone or
> >>>> fax,
> >>>>> contact info is available at:
> >>>>>
> >>>> <http://www.sfgov.org/site/bdsupvrs_index.asp>http://www.sfgov.org/
> >>>> site/bdsu
> >>>> pvrs_index.asp
> >>>>>
> >>>>> Here are some important points about this proposal:
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * Later last call hours will help to keep San Francisco a world
> >>>> class city
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * Later last call hours will create additional revenue for the city
> >>>> and
> >>>> the
> >>>>> state of California
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * San Franciscans should have the same rights as those in other
> >>>> major
> >>>> cities
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * National Traffic Safety Association data indicates that later
> >>>> last call
> >>>>> hours do not increase and may actually decrease the number of
> >>>> alcohol
> >>>>> related traffic fatalities.
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * This proposal applies ONLY to on-site alcohol sales at
> >>>> restaurants,
> >>>> bars,
> >>>>> or nightclubs
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * This proposal DOES NOT allow alcohol sales after 2am in
> >>>> supermarkets or
> >>>>> liquor stores
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * This proposal applies ONLY to restaurants, bars or nightclubs in
> >>>>> districts zoned for late night businesses.
> >>>>>
> >>>>> * This proposal DOES NOT override any local zoning controls.
> >>>>>
> >>>>> Here are the email addresses of our local elected
> >>>>> officials:  <mailto:Aaron.Peskin@sfgov.org>Aaron.Peskin@sfgov.org;

> >>>> nor do
> >>>>> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger
> >>>> is no
> >>>>> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a
> >>>> daring
> >>>>> adventure or nothing."
> >>>>> -Helen Keller
> >>>>>
> >>>>> "Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is
> >>>> the
> >>>>> merger of state and corporate power."
> >>>>> -Benito Mussolini
> >>>>>
> >>>>> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead
> >>>> of the
> >>>>> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
> >>>> become
> >>>>> visible."
> >>>>> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> >>>>
> >>>>
> >>>>

UPLIFT @ SUBLOUNGE SF

Feb 12 2004 @ 07:00pm

`·.,¸¸,.·´¯ U.· P .·L .·I .·F .·T ¯`·.,¸¸,.·´

AuraSF and Cosmic Productions return for their monthly event at the 
Sublounge: "UpLift" 

Every 2nd Thursday of the month 

With beats served up from some of the Bay's greatest @ Sublounge, voted the Bay's #1 "Dance Music" spot and "Best Bar, Best DJ Bar & Best New Club" by SFWeekly and SF Bay Guardian 

Featuring your favorite underground and house sounds. 

Bassment (be carefull going down the stairs): 
-Jack Triumph (progressive) 7:30-10 http://www.jacktriumph.com/
-Forest Green (techno) 10-11:15 http://www.forestgreen.org/gigs/?id=168
-Ethan (tech house) 11:15-12:45 
-Calamity Jane 12:45-cl 

Red Room (watch your step in the entrance): 
-fLOORCRAfT (AuraSF) http://www.progressiveflow.com/
-Iyad (AuraSF)+(Hosstribe)
-Koroma (AuraSF) http://www.mixedelements.com/djbooth.html
-JC (AuraSF) 

Visuals: 
Art by Chris Fabbri http://dear.to/fabbri
trip-out color blast paintings on cotton sheets

YO No Cover All Night / Come As You Are / Dance Hard

$2 Tecates & Buds $3 Well Drinks A lot of free parking and free video games 

Venue: Sublounge!
628 20th Street @ 3rd Street, SF (not to far from SnoDrift on 3rd) 
the sublounge website is http://sublounge.com

http://www.cosmicproductions.org
http://www.aurasf.com

the time: 7pm-2am

Happy Hello !
 
This week on Daytrippin' we join our resident DJ's Buckner and Sean Davis as we welcome:
 
Geebo spinning the funk 
 
  So tune in and Get Down this Saturday to the funky-techy deep house goodliness you know and love. Tune your browser to www.pulseradio.net This and Every Saturday for the very best underground dance music. From 1-4pm EST
 
Pulseradio.net is a global internet radio station featuring 3 hour shows from all over the world! Started in Australia, the pulse crew has grown to represent shows from the U.K., the Far East, All parts of the US including shows from San Fran, New York, Orlando and Miami, South Africa, Boston, and Toronto, Canada.
 
While this email originates with the DJ's of Daytrippin which airs every Saturday from 1-4pm EST, we wish to highlight other shows as well. Here is a small list of the shows broadcast each Saturday as well as their corresponding genre of dance music. For a complete list, visit www.pulseradio.net and view the 'full schedule' for the whole week!
 
ALL TIMES EASTERN STANDARD TIME
5-8am The FatPharm playing Breaks and Bootlegs (AU-Sydney)
10am-1pm Rhythmic Jungle Punch playing Jungle/Drum 'n' Bass (US-Orlando)
1pm-4pm Daytrippin playing House, leaning toward tech and funk (US-Orlando)
4pm-7pm Gettin Smitten playing House, D 'n' B, Downtempo (US-Orlando)
7pm-10pm Euphoric Excursions playing Trance, Prog House and Breaks (US-Orlando)
10pm-1am Energy Guide playing Breaks (US-Orlando)
**Also be sure to check out Evolve from Boston on Mondays 7pm-9pm EST 4pm-6pm PST**
 
 
 
Kindest Regards,
Buckner
vibe is alive    pulseradio.net 
 
 
*****************COMING TO WMC 2004???**************
Check out the Daytrippin' crew on Monday starting at 2pm at the Chesterfield on 8th and Collins as we work the Miami Crowd out!! Come say hi, have a beer and get down!!
 
2-4pm Sean Davis
4-5pm Ernie Turner
5-7pm Buckner

From sfraves-return-110173-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Feb 13 10:29:28 2004

From: DJBigDaddyG@aol.com
Message-ID: <ce.45bc7163.2d5e00fa@aol.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Feb 2004 05:29:14 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1076668154"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5101
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Unlucky No. 13 Friday the 13th combines Christian, pagan beliefs

-------------------------------1076668154
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Friday the 13th is an unlucky day in much of Western Europe, North America, 
and Australia. Many people avoid travel and avoid signing contracts on Friday 
the 13th. Floors in tall buildings often skip from 12 to 14. And while the 
superstition is believed to be fading, it nonetheless has deep roots in both 
Christian and pagan culture.


The Day Jesus Was Crucified?


Many Christians have long believed that Friday was unlucky because it was the 
day of the week when Jesus was crucified. The number 13 was believed to bring 
bad luck because there were 13 people at The Last Supper. Since there were 12 
tribes of Israel, that number was considered lucky.


Roots in Norse Mythology


Thirteen was also a sinister number in Norse mythology. Loki, one of the most 
evil of the Norse gods, went uninvited to a party for 12 at Valhalla, a 
banquet hall of the gods. As a result, he caused the death of Balder, the god of 
light, joy, and reconciliation. Loki tricked Balder's blind brother, Hod, into 
throwing a sprig of mistletoe at Balder's chest. Since mistletoe was the only 
thing on Earth fatal to Balder, the beloved god fell dead.

Literature and Folk Wisdom


During the Middle Ages, the superstition against Friday the 13th grew. On 
Friday, October 13, 1307, King Philip IV of France ordered the arrests of Jaques 
de Molay, Grand Master of the Knights Templars and sixty of his senior knights 
in Paris. Thousands of others were arrested elsewhere in the country. After 
employing torture techniques to compel the Templars to "confess" to wrongdoing, 
most were eventually executed and sympathizers of the Templars condemned 
Friday the 13th as an evil day. Over time a large body of literature and folk 
wisdom have reinforced the belief. In the 18th century, the HMS Friday was 
launched on Friday the 13th. It was never heard from again. Since then, ships are not 
usually launched on that date. (Click here for other mysterious ship 
disappearances.) 


Dinner With 13


It is considered especially unlucky to have 13 people at the table during a 
meal, such as in Agatha Christie's mystery novel, Thirteen at Dinner. During 
the 1880s, a men's group that felt superstition was an unhealthy influence on 
public life held Thirteen Club dinners. Those diners would have doubtless 
deplored Triskaidekaphobia, which is a fear of the number 13. They would also have 
looked askance at Triskaidekamania, which is an excessive enthusiasm for the 
number 13. (Take our Phobias Quiz on Triskaidekaphobia and other scary phobias.)

-------------------------------1076668154--

> The Day Jesus Was Crucified?=20

> Many Christians have long believed that Friday was unlucky because it=

> was the=20
> day of the week when Jesus was crucified=2E The number 13 was believe=
d to=20
> bring=20
> bad luck because there were 13 people at The Last Supper=2E Since the=
re=20
> were 12=20
> tribes of Israel, that number was considered lucky=2E=20

>=20
> Roots in Norse Mythology=20
>=20
>=20
> Thirteen was also a sinister number in Norse mythology=2E Loki, one o=
f the=20
> most=20
> evil of the Norse gods, went uninvited to a party for 12 at Valhalla,=
 a=20
> banquet hall of the gods=2E As a result, he caused the death of Balde=
r,=20
> the god of=20
> light, joy, and reconciliation=2E Loki tricked Balder's blind brother=

s the=20
> only=20
> thing on Earth fatal to Balder, the beloved god fell dead=2E=20
>=20
> Literature and Folk Wisdom=20
>=20
>=20
> During the Middle Ages, the superstition against Friday the 13th grew=
=2E=20
> On=20
> Friday, October 13, 1307, King Philip IV of France ordered the arrest=
s=20

> de Molay, Grand Master of the Knights Templars and sixty of his senio=
r=20
> knights=20
> in Paris=2E Thousands of others were arrested elsewhere in the countr=

> After=20
> employing torture techniques to compel the Templars to "confess" to=20
> wrongdoing,=20
> most were eventually executed and sympathizers of the Templars condem=
ned=20
> Friday the 13th as an evil day=2E Over time a large body of literatur=
e and=20
> folk=20
> wisdom have reinforced the belief=2E In the 18th century, the HMS Fri=
day=20
> was=20
> launched on Friday the 13th=2E It was never heard from again=2E Since=
 then,=20
> ships are not=20
> usually launched on that date=2E (Click here for other mysterious shi=
p=20
> disappearances=2E)=20
>=20
>=20
> Dinner With 13=20
>=20
>=20

> during a=20

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 02:29 AM 2/13/2004, DJBigDaddyG@aol.com wrote:
>Friday the 13th is an unlucky day in much of Western Europe, North America,
>and Australia. Many people avoid travel and avoid signing contracts on Friday
>the 13th. Floors in tall buildings often skip from 12 to 14. And while the
>superstition is believed to be fading, it nonetheless has deep roots in both
>Christian and pagan culture.

On Friday the 13th:  both my grandfather and father had heart attacks (both 
survived);  I was mugged for the first time in NYC by two thugs with knives 
(not hurt, and they didn't get much);  I was on a plane coming into La 
Guardia when the landing gear malfunctioned (plane landed on foam and no 
one was hurt:  on another flight coming into Chicago the landing was 
aborted and we escaped colliding with another plane on the same runway by 
seconds.  Bad luck, good luck -- you decide.  I take it easy, however, on 
these special  Fridays:)

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 http://mokshatribe.org/photos/

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is the 
merger of state and corporate power."
-Benito Mussolini

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

about something like that in order for it not not have the energy to

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [NRR] Unlucky No. 13 Friday the 13th combines
Christian, pagan beliefs


> At 02:29 AM 2/13/2004, DJBigDaddyG@aol.com wrote:
> >Friday the 13th is an unlucky day in much of Western Europe, North
America,
> >and Australia. Many people avoid travel and avoid signing contracts on
Friday
> >the 13th. Floors in tall buildings often skip from 12 to 14. And while
the
> >superstition is believed to be fading, it nonetheless has deep roots in
both
> >Christian and pagan culture.
>
> On Friday the 13th:  both my grandfather and father had heart attacks
(both
> survived);  I was mugged for the first time in NYC by two thugs with
knives
> (not hurt, and they didn't get much);  I was on a plane coming into La
> Guardia when the landing gear malfunctioned (plane landed on foam and no
> one was hurt:  on another flight coming into Chicago the landing was
> aborted and we escaped colliding with another plane on the same runway by
> seconds.  Bad luck, good luck -- you decide.  I take it easy, however, on
> these special  Fridays:)
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>                  http://mokshatribe.org/photos/
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
>
> "Fascism should more properly be called corporatism because it is the
> merger of state and corporate power."
> -Benito Mussolini
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

In a message dated 2/13/2004 10:24:58 AM Pacific Standard Time, DEB62 writes:
In the hospital the relatives gathered in the waiting room, where their 
family member lay gravely ill.

Finally, the doctor came in looking tired and somber.

"I'm afraid I'm the bearer of bad news," he said as he surveyed the worried 
faces.

"The only hope left for your loved one at this time is a brain transplant.

It's an experimental procedure, very risky but it is the only hope.

Insurance will cover the procedure, but you will have to pay for the brain 
yourselves."

The family members sat silent as they absorbed the news. After a great length 
of time, someone asked, "Well, how much does a brain cost?"

The doctor quickly responded, "$5,000 for a male brain, and $200 for a female 
brain."

The moment turned awkward. Men in the room tried not to smile, avoiding eye 
contact with the women, but some actually smirked.

A man unable to control his curiosity, blurted out the question everyone 
wanted to ask,

"Why is the male brain so much more?"

The doctor smiled at the childish innocence and explained to the entire 
group, "It's just standard pricing procedure. We have to mark down the price of the 
female brains, because they've actually been used."

SEND THIS TO A SMART WOMAN WHO NEEDS A LAUGH AND TO THE MEN YOU THINK CAN 
HANDLE IT.

In the hospital the relatives gathered in the waiting room, where their 
family member lay gravely ill.

Finally, the doctor came in looking tired and somber.

"I'm afraid I'm the bearer of bad news," he said as he surveyed the worried 
faces.

"The only hope left for your loved one at this time is a brain transplant.

It's an experimental procedure, very risky but it is the only hope.

Insurance will cover the procedure, but you will have to pay for the brain 
yourselves."

The family members sat silent as they absorbed the news. After a great length 
of time, someone asked, "Well, how much does a brain cost?"

The doctor quickly responded, "$5,000 for a male brain, and $200 for a female 
brain."

The moment turned awkward. Men in the room tried not to smile, avoiding eye 
contact with the women, but some actually smirked.

A man unable to control his curiosity, blurted out the question everyone 
wanted to ask,

"Why is the male brain so much more?"

The doctor smiled at the childish innocence and explained to the entire 
group, "It's just standard pricing procedure. We have to mark down the price of the 
female brains, because they've actually been used."

SEND THIS TO A SMART WOMAN WHO NEEDS A LAUGH AND TO THE MEN YOU THINK CAN 
HANDLE IT.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE:[sfraves] [NRR] Unlucky No. 13 Friday the 13th combines Christian, pagan beliefs

sinister like smoking blunts ?

that 4:20 term came into popularity from a group of teenages years ago
called the waldos (or something like that). It had to do with their kind of
code language for talking about getting smoked after school while they were
in school. . .

funny how that caught on. . .it caught on so huge so quick, most people had
no idea what they were talking about. . .

what other sinister things happened on april 20th, besides of course an ex's
birthday. . .

?

aK
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "spacedoll" <spacedoll@raves.com>
To: <DJBigDaddyG@aol.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, February 13, 2004 1:01 PM
Subject: [sfraves] RE:[sfraves] [NRR] Unlucky No. 13 Friday the 13th
combines Christian, pagan beliefs


Shouldn't there be a phobia about April 20th? There are many sinister
historical connections to that day too.
Humans are funny, funny creatures.

> -----Original Message----- 
> From: <DJBigDaddyG@aol.com&gt ;
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org&gt ;
> Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Unlucky No. 13 Friday the 13th combines
Christian, pagan beliefs
>
>
>
> Friday the 13th is an unlucky day in much of Western Europe, North
> America,
> and Australia. Many people avoid travel and avoid signing contracts on
> Friday
> the 13th. Floors in tall buildings often skip from 12 to 14. And while
> the
> superstition is believed to be fading, it nonetheless has deep roots in
> both
> Christian and pagan culture.
>
>
> The Day Jesus Was Crucified?
>
>
> Many Christians have long believed that Friday was unlucky because it
> was the
> day of the week when Jesus was crucified. The number 13 was believed to
> bring
> bad luck because there were 13 people at The Last Supper. Since there
> were 12
> tribes of Israel, that number was considered lucky.
>
>
> Roots in Norse Mythology
>
>
> Thirteen was also a sinister number in Norse mythology. Loki, one of the
> most
> evil of the Norse gods, went uninvited to a party for 12 at Valhalla, a
> banquet hall of the gods. As a result, he caused the death of Balder,
> the god of
> light, joy, and reconciliation. Loki tricked Balder's blind brother,
> Hod, into
> throwing a sprig of mistletoe at Balder's chest. Since mistletoe was the
> only
> thing on Earth fatal to Balder, the beloved god fell dead.
>
> Literature and Folk Wisdom
>
>
> During the Middle Ages, the superstition against Friday the 13th grew.
> On
> Friday, October 13, 1307, King Philip IV of France ordered the arrests
> of Jaques
> de Molay, Grand Master of the Knights Templars and sixty of his senior
> knights
> in Paris. Thousands of others were arrested elsewhere in the country.
> After
> employing torture techniques to compel the Templars to "confess" to
> wrongdoing,
> most were eventually executed and sympathizers of the Templars condemned
> Friday the 13th as an evil day. Over time a large body of literature and
> folk
> wisdom have reinforced the belief. In the 18th century, the HMS Friday
> was
> launched on Friday the 13th. It was never heard from again. Since then,
> ships are not
> usually launched on that date. (Click here for other mysterious ship
> disappearances.)
>
>
> Dinner With 13
>
>
> It is considered especially unlucky to have 13 people at the table
> during a
> meal, such as in Agatha Christie's mystery novel, Thirteen at Dinner.
> During
> the 1880s, a men's group that felt superstition was an unhealthy
> influence on
> public life held Thirteen Club dinners. Those diners would have
> doubtless
> deplored Triskaidekaphobia, which is a fear of the number 13. They would
> also have
> looked askance at Triskaidekamania, which is an excessive enthusiasm for
> the
> number 13. (Take our Phobias Quiz on Triskaidekaphobia and other scary
> phobias.)
>
>



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Received: (qmail 4800 invoked from network); 13 Feb 2004 22:34:41 -0000
Date: Fri, 13 Feb 2004 14:34:40 -0800 (PST)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040213143246.O60786@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Red Infader Digital Mixer

Has anyone here had a chance to play with one of these? I'd like to know
your opinion... Thanks! Karina


Red Infader Digital Mixer:

http://www.hollywooddj.com/hollywooddj/redinfader.html

Details:

Introducing the World's First Digital Mixer for DJ's Digital mixing offers
incredible audio fidelity, inherent reliability and noise-free fading.
With its modular construction, the RED Sound INFADER allows the user to
choose from a number of crossfading options including the patented
Tri-Fader. This convention-shattering device allows DJ's to crossfade by
selectable bands of frequencies. And with many more modules in the
pipeline, InFader is sure to become a dance classic.

Overview The main mixer section features 2 x input channels with 3 band EQ
(+4/-85dB) and selectable balanced microphone/line level input section
with 2 band EQ. The 'multi-tap' effects send/return loop lets you choose
exactly where to pick-off and return the signal for effects processing and
also doubles-up as an auxiliary stereo line level input for expanded input
capability. With balanced master outputs, crossfader curve control and a
comprehensive monitoring section, INFADER delivers professional mixing
performance at an affordable price. All high usage faders and knobs are
microprocessor controlled assuring extra long life for major hardware
components.

Tri-Fader Module Patent Pending By expanding the traditional single
crossfader section to incorporate 3 crossfaders, each with it's own
high-order digital filter, crossfades can now be broken-down precisely
into low, mid and high frequency bands for stunning crossfade mixing. For
example, the lows from one track can be mixed with the mids and/or highs
from another. Additional features include 3-way/single crossfader select,
reverse function and crossfader 'centre-off' option.

Forthcoming modules for INFADER will include: BPM Module - single
crossfader, V2 BPM engine with 2 x BPM readouts, audio/MIDI sync

BPM Sync Module - single crossfader, 2 channel beat matching, basic
punch-in FX

BPM Auto-Sync Module - single crossfader, 2 channel CD/Vinyl deck speed
control system for automatic BPM lock

BPM FX Module - single crossfader, Multi BPM effects with 2 x BPM readouts

Filter Module - details TBA

--

> > knights
> > in Paris. Thousands of others were arrested elsewhere in the country.
> > After
> > employing torture techniques to compel the Templars to "confess" to
> > wrongdoing,

> > Friday the 13th as an evil day. Over time a large body of literature and
> > folk
> > wisdom have reinforced the belief. In the 18th century, the HMS Friday
> > was

> > ships are not

> > disappearances.)

> >

> > during a

> > During
> > the 1880s, a men's group that felt superstition was an unhealthy
> > influence on

> > doubtless
> > deplored Triskaidekaphobia, which is a fear of the number 13. They would
> > also have

Importance: Normal
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2600.0000
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 13 Feb 2004 22:53:13.0495 (UTC) FILETIME=[290EDA70:01C3F284]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] SRR: Red Infader Digital Mixer

The concept is cool but when I played with it I was not really
impressed. I will stand by my guns and tell people to buy a high end
mixer without the bells and whistles and make sure it has an insert for
FX. You can always buy external FX and route them that way and it sounds
better IMO. The sound quality of a good Allen & Heath or Rane is tough
to beat. I know there are companies out there that have made rackmount
eq setups for kills and other assorted mixing tools. 

Jason 

-----Original Message-----
From: Karina [mailto:karina@hyperreal.org]

Red Infader Digital Mixer:
