> >
> >On Mon, Feb 23, 2004 at 12:50:27AM -0800, Starchild wrote:
> >>	Fortunately there is less reason to freak out about climate change
> >>than most media reports would have us believe. There is no consensus  
> >>in
> >>the scientific community on whether global warming is a good thing or  
> >>a
> >>bad thing, or whether it's caused by humans or not. But previous
> >>disaster scenarios from many of the environmental extremists now
> >>pushing climate change scare stories turned out to be -- a lot of hot
> >>air. Below is an article from the national Libertarian Party  
> >>newsletter
> >>debunking some of the myths.
> >>
> >>	The AIDS scare has likewise been blown out of proportion. In 1987,
> >>Oprah Winfrey said, "Research studies now project that one in five --
> >>listen to me, hard to believe -- one in five heterosexuals could be
> >>dead from AIDS at the end of the next three years... Believe me."   
> >>That
> >>would have been 44 million people dead. Obviously reality didn't quite
> >>turn out that way. (Did Oprah ever apologize for scaring the shit out
> >>of people and contributing to stress-related health problems by making
> >>them more stressed out? Probably not.) According to a March 2004
> >>article in Details magazine (the source of the preceding information),
> >>the truth is that the AIDS epidemic in this country peaked in 1993,
> >>with 106,000 new cases. Now there are only 40,000 new cases a year,  
> >>and
> >>only 16,371 people in the U.S. died of AIDS in 2002. Of course that's
> >>still a lot, and every death is one too many, but the total pales
> >>compared to cancer (554,000 deaths in 2001), diabetes (71,000 deaths)
> >>or Alzheimer's disease (54,000 deaths).
> >>
> >>	And there's no evidence that global warming has killed anyone, yet
> >>	its advocates want to spend a ton of money to change human  
> >>activities that
> >>may or may not even be causing this alleged "problem," which is money
> >>that won't be there to fight diseases and address other problems that
> >>really are costing lives.
> >>
> >>					<<< Starchild >>>
> >>
> >>
> >>>Making sense of the global warming 'crisis'
> >>>
> >>>by Bill Winter
> >>>LP News Editor
> >>>
> >>>Global warming is going to kill your children. At least, that's the
> >>>claim of a significant number of scientists and politicians.
> >>>
> >>>They say global warming will cause the world's temperature to rise by
> >>>as much as 5.8 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century. That, in  
> >>>turn,
> >>>will cause the ice caps to melt, sea levels to rise, epidemics of
> >>>tropical diseases to rage across the globe, and cataclysmic storms  
> >>>and
> >>>droughts to destroy crops and cities.
> >>>
> >>>Are they correct? To answer that, we must first answer four other
> >>>questions:
> >>>
> >>>1) Is the earth really getting warmer?
> >>>
> >>>2) If it's getting warmer, is human activity causing it?
> >>>
> >>>3) How much warmer might it get?
> >>>
> >>>4) How bad might the effects be?
> >>>
> >>>Environmentalists get indignant if you ask the first two questions.
> >>>They say the science is so definitive that anyone who questions  
> >>>global
> >>>warming is a crackpot.
> >>>
> >>>For example, former vice president and amateur climatologist Al Gore
> >>>compared critics of global warming to tobacco company executives who
> >>>lied about the dangers of cigarettes. Fairness & Accuracy In  
> >>>Reporting
> >>>(FAIR) called ABC News commentator John Stosell a "free-market  
> >>>zealot"
> >>>for questioning global warming doom-and-gloom scenarios.
> >>>
> >>>Environmentalists also say they know the answers to the third and
> >>>fourth questions. Gore claimed in his 1993 book Earth in the Balance
> >>>that "every coastal country will suffer adverse effects" from rising
> >>>sea levels, and that "pests, germs, and viruses [will] migrate with  
> >>>the
> >>>changing climate patterns," threatening the lives of "hundreds of
> >>>millions of people."
> >>>
> >>>Raising the rhetorical ante even more was Sir John Houghton, co-chair
> >>>of the U.N.'s Scientific Assessment Working Group of the
> >>>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, who proclaimed that
> >>>"human-induced climate change is a weapon of mass destruction."
> >>>
> >>>Are they correct? Are we polluting ourselves into an environmental
> >>>apocalypse?
> >>>
> >>>But first: What exactly is "global warming"?
> >>>
> >>>It's the theory that gasses -- primarily carbon dioxide (CO2),  
> >>>methane
> >>>(CH4), and nitrous oxide (N02) -- created by burning fossil fuels  
> >>>like
> >>>oil and coal collect in the atmosphere, trapping heat and causing
> >>>global temperatures to rise.
> >>>
> >>>The theory was first expounded by Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius in
> >>>1896. At the time, Arrhenius was concerned about smoke caused by  
> >>>coal,
> >>>which was burned to fuel the industrial revolution.
> >>>
> >>>No one paid much attention until the 1950s, when some hotter than  
> >>>usual
> >>>summers prompted Scripps Institution of Oceanography Director Roger
> >>>Revelle to revive the theory.
> >>>
> >>>However, by the 1960s, global warming had been supplanted by a new
> >>>theory -- global cooling. A two-decades long chill caused scientists  
> >>>to
> >>>warn that atmospheric smoke and dust were leading inexorably to a new
> >>>Ice Age. The only debate, noted John Shanahan in a Heritage  
> >>>Foundation
> >>>Backgrounder (May 21, 1992) was "how soon it would come and how
> >>>devastating the cold would be."
> >>>
> >>>To the surprise of many, glaciers failed to cover the earth. Instead,
> >>>temperatures crept back up, leading to another revival of the global
> >>>warming theory. In 1975, the first computer-simulated climate model
> >>>(called a General Circulation Model, or GCM) was introduced. It
> >>>predicted that CO2 would cause sustained temperature increases.
> >>>
> >>>In 1988, James Hansen, chief of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space
> >>>Studies, told the U.S. Senate that global warming had arrived, and  
> >>>"we
> >>>can ascribe with a high degree of confidence a cause and effect
> >>>relationship" to human activity.
> >>>
> >>>Alarmed, the United Nations created the Intergovernmental Panel on
> >>>Climate Change (IPCC) in 1988 to study "human-induced climate  
> >>>change."
> >>>
> >>>The panel issued a report that declared a "balance of evidence  
> >>>suggests
> >>>a discernible human influence on the global climate." Using computer
> >>>models, it predicted that global temperatures could increase by 5.8
> >>>degrees by 2100.
> >>>
> >>>That prognostication inspired the Kyoto Protocol (named after the
> >>>Japanese city in which it was negotiated). The treaty called for
> >>>industrialized countries to reduce greenhouse gases by 7% by 2012.
> >>>However, the Kyoto Protocol can't take effect until it is ratified by
> >>>55 nations, including industrialized nations that produce 55% of the
> >>>world's greenhouse gases.
> >>>
> >>>The U.S. Senate has refused to ratify it, citing the massive cost of
> >>>compliance. By some estimates, the curbs in energy production  
> >>>mandated
> >>>by the Kyoto Protocol could cause the U.S. GDP to fall by $318  
> >>>billion
> >>>and could destroy 3.1 million jobs.
> >>>
> >>>Meanwhile, the global warming debate goes on. Which leads us back to
> >>>our four questions...
> >>>
> >>>* Is the earth really getting warmer?
> >>>
> >>>Probably. But only a little.
> >>>
> >>>Over the last 100 years, the Earth's temperature has increased about
> >>>one degree Fahrenheit, according to S. Fred Singer in Environment  
> >>>News
> >>>(November 21, 2003).
> >>>
> >>>However, as noted in the Cato Handbook for the 107th Congress, a
> >>>significant portion of that warming occurred between 1910 to 1940 --
> >>>"and likely had little if anything to do with changes in the earth's
> >>>greenhouse effect, as three-quarters of the greenhouse emissions
> >>>occurred in the [post-World War II] era."
> >>>
> >>>Since then, temperatures have flattened out. In fact, by 1996, 100
> >>>climate scientists signed the Leipzig Declaration, which stated,  
> >>>"Most
> >>>scientists now accept the fact that actual observations from Earth
> >>>satellites show no climate warming whatsoever."
> >>>
> >>>* If it's getting warmer, is human activity causing it?
> >>>
> >>>Possibly. There is evidence that human-created CO2 has nudged global
> >>>temperatures up slightly in the 20th century.
> >>>
> >>>But the proof is not conclusive; other evidence suggests that the  
> >>>rise
> >>>in temperature is part of long-term, natural cycles.
> >>>
> >>>We do know this: Levels of CO2 in the atmosphere have increased by
> >>>about 30% -- from 280 parts per million (ppm) to about 365 ppm --  
> >>>over
> >>>the past millennium.
> >>>
> >>>However, human beings play only a small role in the production of  
> >>>CO2.
> >>>As a documentary on England's Channel 4 Television noted in 1997:
> >>>"Oceans emit 90 billion tons of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse
> >>>gas, every year. Decaying plants throw up another 90 billion tons,
> >>>compared to just six billion tons a year from humans."
> >>>
> >>>A study of historic records, tree rings, and ice cores also reveals
> >>>that there have been significant climate fluctuations through the  
> >>>ages.
> >>>
> >>>For example, there was a centuries-long warming spell -- called the
> >>>Medieval Warm Period -- that allowed Vikings to settle in Greenland  
> >>>in
> >>>982 A.D. The now-snow covered island had pockets of lush greenery  
> >>>and a
> >>>hospitable growing season back then, and more than 1,000  
> >>>Scandinavians
> >>>thrived there.
> >>>
> >>>Thrived for about 200 years, that is. Then, the so-called Little Ice
> >>>Age chilled the entire Western hemisphere. By 1480 A.D., all the
> >>>Greenland Vikings had fled or starved to death during icy winters.
> >>>
> >>>During the Little Ice Age, the Thames river in London froze, famines
> >>>became more frequent as crops failed because of shorter growing
> >>>seasons, and glaciers advanced out of the Swiss Alps.
> >>>
> >>>(Interesting historical side note: Researchers now think that Antonio
> >>>Stradivari made such heavenly sounding violins because of the Little
> >>>Ice Age. USA Today reported on December 2, 2003 that the cold winters
> >>>and cool summers stunted Alpine Spruce tree growth in Europe, making
> >>>the wood denser, and giving it special acoustic properties.  
> >>>Stradivari
> >>>made his famous violins from 1700 to 1720, right in the middle of the
> >>>Little Ice Age.)
> >>>
> >>>Scientists who measure today's temperatures against the
> >>>colder-than-average Little Ice Age, which lasted from the mid-14th
> >>>century until about 1850, are "exaggerating the significance of  
> >>>today's
> >>>temperature rise," said the Wikipedia Encyclopedia.
> >>>
> >>>If the planet is getting warmer again, what is turning up the
> >>>thermostat? One possible answer: The sun.
> >>>
> >>>In a study in the journal Physical Review Letters and publicized in  
> >>>the
> >>>Washington Times (November 3, 2003), European scientists reported  
> >>>that
> >>>the sun has been more active during the last half-century than at
> >>>anytime in the last 1,150 years.
> >>>
> >>>Scientists from the Max Planck Institute for Aeronomy and the
> >>>University of Oulu say sunspots are at a millennium-high level. They
> >>>calculated this based on radioactive isotopes preserved in ice cores
> >>>from Greenland and Antarctica.
> >>>
> >>>The European scientists did not claim that the sunspots contribute to
> >>>global warming. However, as the Washington Times reported, "Their  
> >>>work
> >>>will probably be noted by those who claim temperature rises during  
> >>>the
> >>>past century are the result of changes in the Sun's output."
> >>>
> >>>* How much hotter might it get?
> >>>
> >>>According to the latest "best guess" by the IPCC's computer models,  
> >>>the
> >>>Earth's temperature will increase by 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit by 2100.
> >>>
> >>>However, as Joseph L. Bast noted in Heartland Policy Study No. 88
> >>>(October 1, 1998), the IPCC's computer models are "unable to  
> >>>replicate
> >>>past climate trends."
> >>>
> >>>In other words, when they run the models backwards, and attempt to
> >>>recreate the temperature fluctuations that have actually occurred  
> >>>over
> >>>the past 100 years, the computer generates numbers that "do not even
> >>>overlap" with reality. Such "unreliable" results show that the  
> >>>computer
> >>>models are "too crude to predict future climate changes," wrote Bast.
> >>>
> >>>Other scientists say the temperature increase could be 2.25 degrees
> >>>Fahrenheit, according to Jerry Taylor, the director of natural  
> >>>resource
> >>>studies at the Cato Institute.
> >>>
> >>>If temperatures continue to creep upwards as they have during the  
> >>>last
> >>>century, the increase could be as little as 1.35 degrees Fahrenheit,
> >>>said Patrick J. Michaels, author of The Satanic Gases.
> >>>
> >>>Why the big difference in projections? Because "climatology is  
> >>>perhaps
> >>>one of the most complex and uncertain of all scientific fields,"  
> >>>wrote
> >>>the Heritage Foundation's John Shanahan. "It is not possible to run
> >>>controlled experiments for the whole planet in a laboratory test  
> >>>tube.
> >>>Thus, scientists are forced to use models to predict the consequences
> >>>of various influences, and to try to disentangle the effect of one
> >>>factor from a myriad of others."
> >>>
> >>>The bottom line: No one knows for sure.
> >>>
> >>>* How bad might the effects be?
> >>>
> >>>If you believe Al Gore, the effects of global warming will rival  
> >>>those
> >>>of the Black Death.
> >>>
> >>>Real scientists aren't so sure. Writing in Heartland Policy Study No.
> >>>88, Bast noted that a "a slightly warmer world would probably be
> >>>greener and a little cloudier than our world today, but otherwise not
> >>>much different."
> >>>
> >>>Dennis T. Avery, writing on www.GlobalWarming.org (September 1,  
> >>>1998),
> >>>said a two degree increase in temperate would mean "milder winters,
> >>>fewer storms, only a slight increase in daytime summer temperatures,
> >>>and more carbon dioxide to fertilize crops and pastures."
> >>>
> >>>Higher concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere would "improve
> >>>agricultural production," agreed the Heritage Foundation's Shanahan.
> >>>"Studies conducted by the Department of Agriculture's Agricultural
> >>>Research Service show that doubling the CO2 concentration in the
> >>>atmosphere would improve cotton yields by 80%, wheat and rice by 36%,
> >>>soybeans by 32%, and corn by 16%."
> >>>
> >>>However, those benefits could be tempered by flooding and more
> >>>unpredictable weather, say other researchers.
> >>>
> >>>In other words: No one can be sure "whether any changes in global
> >>>temperature would be beneficial or detrimental," said Shanahan.
> >>>
> >>>Conclusion
> >>>
> >>>There is no "official" Libertarian position on the debate over global
> >>>warming.
> >>>
> >>>Libertarianism -- a political philosophy -- cannot say whether the
> >>>Earth is warming, or what causes long-term climate change, or what  
> >>>the
> >>>impact of a warming planet might be. Ultimately, those are scientific
> >>>questions that will be answered by scientists.
> >>>
> >>>However, most libertarians will view global warming through a
> >>>libertarian sensibility.
> >>>
> >>>That sensibility was best summarized by H.L. Mencken, who said, "The
> >>>whole aim of practical politics is to keep the populace alarmed and
> >>>hence clamoring to be led to safety -- by menacing it with an endless
> >>>series of hobgoblins, all of them imaginary."
> >>>
> >>>For politicians, global warming is the perfect hobgoblin.
> >>>
> >>>Politicians like Al Gore tell us that only government (and the Kyoto
> >>>Protocol) can save future generations from an environmental plague of
> >>>Biblical proportions.
> >>>
> >>>Without new taxes on energy sources (oil, gasoline, and coal);  
> >>>without
> >>>new regulations on automobiles and power plants; without
> >>>government-funded research into alternative energy sources -- in  
> >>>other
> >>>words, without a raft of new taxes and regulations -- the planet is
> >>>doomed, they say.
> >>>
> >>>As Bast wrote in Heartland Policy Study No. 88, "Virtually all  
> >>>economic
> >>>activities involve the use of energy and consequently the release of
> >>>greenhouse gases." Therefore, he wrote, politicians' proposals "to
> >>>limit greenhouse gases is a license for governments to monitor, tax,
> >>>regulate, or ban virtually any activity."
> >>>
> >>>Giving that power to politicians -- to "monitor, tax, regulate, or  
> >>>ban
> >>>virtually any activity" -- is not something that any Libertarian  
> >>>could
> >>>endorse.
> >>>
> >>>That's why the best solution to the possible threat of global warming
> >>>may be what Bast calls the "no regrets" policy.
> >>>
> >>>It consists of investing "in atmospheric research to determine  
> >>>whether
> >>>a genuine threat exists, and [investing] in reducing emissions only
> >>>when such investments make economic sense in their own right."
> >>>
> >>>Under such a plan, government could help by reducing taxes and
> >>>eliminating regulations to "encourage new investments in capital and
> >>>technology, thereby speeding up the process of phasing out  
> >>>inefficient
> >>>machinery [that produce greenhouse gasses]."
> >>>
> >>>Such a policy, wrote Bast, "promises much superior results without  
> >>>the
> >>>enormous social costs and losses of liberty" that would result from
> >>>giving politicians the almost unlimited power they say they need to
> >>>"fix" global warming.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>On Sunday, February 22, 2004, at 07:25  PM, Apollo wrote:
> >>
> >>>Who knows?  We all live in a consensus reality and if we didn't we
> >>>would probably all need hefty supplies of valium or somethin'....
> >>>
> >>>For example, this just comes across my desk.  Enjoy yourself.  It's
> >>>later than you think:)
> >>>
> >>>Now the Pentagon tells Bush: climate change will destroy us
> >>>
> >>>· Secret report warns of rioting and nuclear war
> >>>· Britain will be 'Siberian' in less than 20 years
> >>>· Threat to the world is greater than terrorism
> >>>
> >>>Mark Townsend and Paul Harris in New York
> >>>
> >>>Sunday February 22, 2004: (The Observer) Climate change over the next
> >>>20 years could result in a global catastrophe costing millions of
> >>>lives in wars and natural disasters..
> >>>
> >>>A secret report, suppressed by US defence chiefs and obtained by The
> >>>Observer, warns that major European cities will be sunk beneath  
> >>>rising
> >>>seas as Britain is plunged into a 'Siberian' climate by 2020. Nuclear
> >>>conflict, mega-droughts, famine and widespread rioting will erupt
> >>>across the world.
> >>>
> >>>The document predicts that abrupt climate change could bring the
> >>>planet to the edge of anarchy as countries develop a nuclear threat  
> >>>to
> >>>defend and secure dwindling food, water and energy supplies. The
> >>>threat to global stability vastly eclipses that of terrorism, say the
> >>>few experts privy to its contents.
> >>>
> >>>'Disruption and conflict will be endemic features of life,' concludes
> >>>the Pentagon analysis. 'Once again, warfare would define human life.'
> >>>
> >>>The findings will prove humiliating to the Bush administration, which
> >>>has repeatedly denied that climate change even exists. Experts said
> >>>that they will also make unsettling reading for a President who has
> >>>insisted national defence is a priority.
> >>>
> >>>The report was commissioned by influential Pentagon defence adviser
> >>>Andrew Marshall, who has held considerable sway on US military
> >>>thinking over the past three decades. He was the man behind a  
> >>>sweeping
> >>>recent review aimed at transforming the American military under
> >>>Defence Secretary Donald Rumsfeld.
> >>>
> >>>Climate change 'should be elevated beyond a scientific debate to a US
> >>>national security concern', say the authors, Peter Schwartz, CIA
> >>>consultant and former head of planning at Royal Dutch/Shell Group,  
> >>>and
> >>>Doug Randall of the California-based Global Business Network.
> >>>
> >>>An imminent scenario of catastrophic climate change is 'plausible and
> >>>would challenge United States national security in ways that should  
> >>>be
> >>>considered immediately', they conclude. As early as next year
> >>>widespread flooding by a rise in sea levels will create major  
> >>>upheaval
> >>>for millions.
> >>>
> >>>Last week the Bush administration came under heavy fire from a large
> >>>body of respected scientists who claimed that it cherry-picked  
> >>>science
> >>>to suit its policy agenda and suppressed studies that it did not  
> >>>like.
> >>>Jeremy Symons, a former whistleblower at the Environmental Protection
> >>>Agency (EPA), said that suppression of the report for four months was
> >>>a further example of the White House trying to bury the threat of
> >>>climate change.
> >>>
> >>>Senior climatologists, however, believe that their verdicts could
> >>>prove the catalyst in forcing Bush to accept climate change as a real
> >>>and happening phenomenon. They also hope it will convince the United
> >>>States to sign up to global treaties to reduce the rate of climatic
> >>>change.
> >>>
> >>>A group of eminent UK scientists recently visited the White House to
> >>>voice their fears over global warming, part of an intensifying drive
> >>>to get the US to treat the issue seriously. Sources have told The
> >>>Observer that American officials appeared extremely sensitive about
> >>>the issue when faced with complaints that America's public stance
> >>>appeared increasingly out of touch.
> >>>
> >>>One even alleged that the White House had written to complain about
> >>>some of the comments attributed to Professor Sir David King, Tony
> >>>Blair's chief scientific adviser, after he branded the President's
> >>>position on the issue as indefensible.
> >>>
> >>>Among those scientists present at the White House talks were  
> >>>Professor
> >>>John Schellnhuber, former chief environmental adviser to the German
> >>>government and head of the UK's leading group of climate scientists  
> >>>at
> >>>the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research. He said that the
> >>>Pentagon's internal fears should prove the 'tipping point' in
> >>>persuading Bush to accept climatic change.
> >>>
> >>>Sir John Houghton, former chief executive of the Meteorological  
> >>>Office
> >>>- and the first senior figure to liken the threat of climate change  
> >>>to
> >>>that of terrorism - said: 'If the Pentagon is sending out that sort  
> >>>of
> >>>message, then this is an important document indeed.'
> >>>
> >>>Bob Watson, chief scientist for the World Bank and former chair of  
> >>>the
> >>>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, added that the Pentagon's
> >>>dire warnings could no longer be ignored.
> >>>
> >>>'Can Bush ignore the Pentagon? It's going be hard to blow off this
> >>>sort of document. Its hugely embarrassing. After all, Bush's single
> >>>highest priority is national defence. The Pentagon is no wacko,
> >>>liberal group, generally speaking it is conservative. If climate
> >>>change is a threat to national security and the economy, then he has
> >>>to act. There are two groups the Bush Administration tend to listen
> >>>to, the oil lobby and the Pentagon,' added Watson.
> >>>
> >>>'You've got a President who says global warming is a hoax, and across
> >>>the Potomac river you've got a Pentagon preparing for climate wars.
> >>>It's pretty scary when Bush starts to ignore his own government on
> >>>this issue,' said Rob Gueterbock of Greenpeace.
> >>>
> >>>Already, according to Randall and Schwartz, the planet is carrying a
> >>>higher population than it can sustain. By 2020 'catastrophic'
> >>>shortages of water and energy supply will become increasingly harder
> >>>to overcome, plunging the planet into war. They warn that 8,200 years
> >>>ago climatic conditions brought widespread crop failure, famine,
> >>>disease and mass migration of populations that could soon be  
> >>>repeated.
> >>>
> >>>Randall told The Observer that the potential ramifications of rapid
> >>>climate change would create global chaos. 'This is depressing stuff,'
> >>>he said. 'It is a national security threat that is unique because
> >>>there is no enemy to point your guns at and we have no control over
> >>>the threat.'
> >>>
> >>>Randall added that it was already possibly too late to prevent a
> >>>disaster happening. 'We don't know exactly where we are in the
> >>>process. It could start tomorrow and we would not know for another
> >>>five years,' he said.
> >>>
> >>>'The consequences for some nations of the climate change are
> >>>unbelievable. It seems obvious that cutting the use of fossil fuels
> >>>would be worthwhile.'
> >>>
> >>>So dramatic are the report's scenarios, Watson said, that they may
> >>>prove vital in the US elections. Democratic frontrunner John Kerry is
> >>>known to accept climate change as a real problem. Scientists
> >>>disillusioned with Bush's stance are threatening to make sure Kerry
> >>>uses the Pentagon report in his campaign.
> >>>
> >>>The fact that Marshall is behind its scathing findings will aid
> >>>Kerry's cause. Marshall, 82, is a Pentagon legend who heads a
> >>>secretive think-tank dedicated to weighing risks to national security
> >>>called the Office of Net Assessment. Dubbed 'Yoda' by Pentagon
> >>>insiders who respect his vast experience, he is credited with being
> >>>behind the Department of Defence's push on ballistic-missile defence.
> >>>
> >>>Symons, who left the EPA in protest at political interference, said
> >>>that the suppression of the report was a further instance of the  
> >>>White
> >>>House trying to bury evidence of climate change. 'It is yet another
> >>>example of why this government should stop burying its head in the
> >>>sand on this issue.'
> >>>
> >>>Symons said the Bush administration's close links to high-powered
> >>>energy and oil companies was vital in understanding why climate  
> >>>change
> >>>was received sceptically in the Oval Office. 'This administration is
> >>>ignoring the evidence in order to placate a handful of large energy

aK <aK@hard-grooves.com> wrote:
hehe,

it's cool to be cynical, but by no way is it a chupacabra, or something that
has to be "believed in".
It is real, and it does effect people in these areas. Moreso also than any
other area in the country. I believe it's due to the issues and
complications involved with the population density and visitors to the
areas.

lemmee, think . . .

well, hmm. . .I guess it doesn't matter who I tell now .. .

Well KTVU just left my house a lil bit ago, I was being interviewed cuz I'm
one of these people with this mysterious skin disease. (thats kind of a load
off my back)
I've had this over a year now, I've gone thru the worst this disease has to
offer. No one believed me till I found those websites and spoke to people
like me, and still I felt as if I was so worse off cuz I had all of those
symptoms plus some. . .it is an absolutely horrible disease. . .during it my
body was being destroyed, I was sick constantly, getting weird infections
here and there, dealing with the lesions that randomly appeared all over my
body. . .there were times when things got so badd that I was actually
starting to go nuts, I was stuttering a lot, I had a hard time completing
coherant sentences. . .I got out of that, but it shows how much strain
mentally this puts people thru. Since no one believed me, my friends,
family, the doctors I saw. . .theres no real cure, or chemical that's
worked. . .Theres just no where to turn.
I could go into what I've seen but it would take quite a while, I will if
you want. I've seen things on a weekly basis that I never could have
imagined would ever happen. It's really something like out of an old horror
movie. Scary shit like large bumps moving under your skin, lots of times
entering seriously EVERY opening into my body. . .eyes, mouth, nose, ears,
everything below the belt. . .
It is real. . .

I'm not sure if this is actually wear it started , but I was working under
my car for a long period and there was a night when I went inside and found
all sorts of fat bright red tracks all over my shoulders. . .then the weird
tingle in the center of my back, then a course of things from scabies to
tapeworms, to weird granules, to hairs that weren't mine, to lesions. . .it
all eventually ended up with this one organism taking everything over and
after that all I see is the bumps, the granules, and the hair. . .
I think things were tracked into my driveway from the animals coming thru. I
was seeing racoons and such who would come thru all the time. There was a
housing development that started about 2 years ago that displaced all sorts
of things from their homes, and thats right next to this big water treatment
place on the bay. . .

Its hard to tell if I had minor symptoms before or not. ..but NOTHING
compared to the shit that happened to me in the past year. . .I'm telling
you, you couldn't imagine most of the shit, it all sounds crazy, and still
does to me, but it's true.
My symtoms have gotten better with the taking of ionic copper and silver
supplements. It's pretty much the only thing any of us have tried that
works. I've been taking them for maybe 3 mos, and my skin has definately
improved. The news guys shot some of my marks, but I gave em a cd with pics
I took from other times when it was just fukked up. . .

I'm not sure what to say about infecting other people in contact with you. .
.I have a close friend who used to live with me and moved away over a year
ago, she came to visit and shortly after going back home she's experiencing
lesions n such. . .so she might have gotten an early form of it when she
lived with me, but her symptoms escalated after going thru her old boxes
over here when she had to ship the stuff back. . . so who knows, I have a
relative who lives with me who doesn't have it, my dad doesn't, my sis
doesn't. . .my cat does, and the friends who I've hung out with since then
don't. . .

??
An important thing to consider is that we're not dirty people. . .have, or
had normal lives till this. I know theres another person in this area who's
whole family has it. Shit, at the worst points, I was spending like 4+hours
in the shower and bath. . . a couple a day. . . it was one of the only
places that were somewhat comfortable if I was having a really bad day, like
referring to skin issues. Most of my day would be spent showering, shaving,
washing everything around me, all sorts of stuff. It's a good thing I've
pretty much been shaving my whole body since I was like 16ish.


but so, well now ya know. . .
I'm totally open to questions or comments. . .I'm seeing more and more
people come out lately and it's obvious that this issue is growing. . .I
want to help other people with this who may think they have it or know or
whatever, a lot of people with this become suicidal or commit suicide due to
the difficulty finding help in any sort. Thats the main reason I agreed to
be on a news bit about it. I don't care what people think about me, but I
don't want people to have to go thru what I know I've been thru. . .

I can expain more later, but this is very long already. . .

take care all
: )

aK

> > > It's really creepy, scary, absolutely horrible. Theres more and more
people
> > > every day coming out with this illness. A lot of these people are
being
> > > institutionalized because everyone they know and turn to think they're
> > > crazy, but it's definately real. It's a relatively unknown epidemic
thats
> > > plaging thousands of people. Doctors are pretty much completely
uneducated
> > > on the subject, and some who seem like they might know something end
up
> > > hiding it like some sort of conspiracy. Even the CA state health
department
> > > is ignoring the matter.
> >
> > What evidence do you have that it's "real" other than some pictures on
the
> > internet and some people who say they're infected? Sounds about as
"real"
> > as the chupacabara.
> >
>
> After doing a little bit of private digging, I have no doubt that there
> is something causing a strange skin disease that is hard to diagnose
> because of the strange fibrous growths that the lesions produce, or maybe
> I should say 'has caused.' I didn't see anything about it in the modern
> era.
>
>
> > > I think this is a serious issue for people like us, who frequent
parties
> > > with large numbers of close quartered people, in old wherehouses,
buildings,
> > > and areas that are likely to be heavily infested with these creatures.
> >
> > Do you have an specific reason to believe that the parasites are
> > transmitted simply from being in close quarters with other people? Or
> > that the parasites live in old warehouses or buildings? Has there been
> > research on the mode of transmission?
> >
>
> I think that aK is mistaken as to the vector. On the morgellons.org
> website, a page talks about how a significant majority of those suffering
> from this outbreak also test positive for the BB bacteria that causes Lyme
> disease, which is, as you should know from your cynical epidemiologist
> hat, a disease that is not as well understood as some others and which
> does seem to have some undetermined function against the immune system.
> Lyme disease, though, is fairly well traceable to a certain tick, which
> might mean that there's a chance that OUTDOOR parties are a risk.
>
> All in all, it's something to keep on the back burner for awhile, I think.
> aK is (semi)obviously a little more prone to the conspiracy theory than
> most of us are. Not to say he/she/it's a liar, not at all. Just that we
> need more evidence or even more verifiable anecdotes and reserve judgment
> until then.
>
> I bet it's more real than the Chupacabra, though.
>
> -jon

aparrantly they were contacted several times by people and organizations and
were pretty much referred to going to a university medical center, or
specific physicians. Most people are usually evaluated with delisional
parasitosis, or explained with various skin infection names.

I've tried contacting people and places and have talked to others who
contacted other places and organizations. It sucks really. . .most
organizations totally ignore the issue. This ktvu thing was part from people
contacting people. . . it's unreal almost and it really seems like people
are purposely ignoring things. . .this is one of the issues I have firsthand
experience with .. .

besides all of that, most other people think they're nuts and not sick and
therefor don't seek medical help, or even if they do they're prescribed
drugs of some sort (antidepressant usually)that never work, etc etc. . .
everyone I speak to has the same issues with their doctors n such. . .

> aK <aK@hard-grooves.com> wrote:
> hehe,
>
> it's cool to be cynical, but by no way is it a chupacabra, or something
that
> has to be "believed in".
> It is real, and it does effect people in these areas. Moreso also than any
> other area in the country. I believe it's due to the issues and
> complications involved with the population density and visitors to the
> areas.
>
> lemmee, think . . .
>
> well, hmm. . .I guess it doesn't matter who I tell now .. .
>
> Well KTVU just left my house a lil bit ago, I was being interviewed cuz
I'm
> one of these people with this mysterious skin disease. (thats kind of a
load
> off my back)
> I've had this over a year now, I've gone thru the worst this disease has
to
> offer. No one believed me till I found those websites and spoke to people
> like me, and still I felt as if I was so worse off cuz I had all of those
> symptoms plus some. . .it is an absolutely horrible disease. . .during it
my
> body was being destroyed, I was sick constantly, getting weird infections
> here and there, dealing with the lesions that randomly appeared all over
my
> body. . .there were times when things got so badd that I was actually
> starting to go nuts, I was stuttering a lot, I had a hard time completing
> coherant sentences. . .I got out of that, but it shows how much strain
> mentally this puts people thru. Since no one believed me, my friends,
> family, the doctors I saw. . .theres no real cure, or chemical that's
> worked. . .Theres just no where to turn.
> I could go into what I've seen but it would take quite a while, I will if
> you want. I've seen things on a weekly basis that I never could have
> imagined would ever happen. It's really something like out of an old
horror
> movie. Scary shit like large bumps moving under your skin, lots of times
> entering seriously EVERY opening into my body. . .eyes, mouth, nose, ears,
> everything below the belt. . .
> It is real. . .
>
> I'm not sure if this is actually wear it started , but I was working under
> my car for a long period and there was a night when I went inside and
found
> all sorts of fat bright red tracks all over my shoulders. . .then the
weird
> tingle in the center of my back, then a course of things from scabies to
> tapeworms, to weird granules, to hairs that weren't mine, to lesions. .
.it
> all eventually ended up with this one organism taking everything over and
> after that all I see is the bumps, the granules, and the hair. . .
> I think things were tracked into my driveway from the animals coming thru.
I
> was seeing racoons and such who would come thru all the time. There was a
> housing development that started about 2 years ago that displaced all
sorts
> of things from their homes, and thats right next to this big water
treatment
> place on the bay. . .
>
> Its hard to tell if I had minor symptoms before or not. ..but NOTHING
> compared to the shit that happened to me in the past year. . .I'm telling
> you, you couldn't imagine most of the shit, it all sounds crazy, and still
> does to me, but it's true.
> My symtoms have gotten better with the taking of ionic copper and silver
> supplements. It's pretty much the only thing any of us have tried that
> works. I've been taking them for maybe 3 mos, and my skin has definately
> improved. The news guys shot some of my marks, but I gave em a cd with
pics
> I took from other times when it was just fukked up. . .
>
> I'm not sure what to say about infecting other people in contact with you.
.
> .I have a close friend who used to live with me and moved away over a year
> ago, she came to visit and shortly after going back home she's
experiencing
> lesions n such. . .so she might have gotten an early form of it when she
> lived with me, but her symptoms escalated after going thru her old boxes
> over here when she had to ship the stuff back. . . so who knows, I have a
> relative who lives with me who doesn't have it, my dad doesn't, my sis
> doesn't. . .my cat does, and the friends who I've hung out with since then
> don't. . .
>
> ??
> An important thing to consider is that we're not dirty people. . .have, or
> had normal lives till this. I know theres another person in this area
who's
> whole family has it. Shit, at the worst points, I was spending like
4+hours
> in the shower and bath. . . a couple a day. . . it was one of the only
> places that were somewhat comfortable if I was having a really bad day,
like
> referring to skin issues. Most of my day would be spent showering,
shaving,
> washing everything around me, all sorts of stuff. It's a good thing I've
> pretty much been shaving my whole body since I was like 16ish.
>
>
> but so, well now ya know. . .
> I'm totally open to questions or comments. . .I'm seeing more and more
> people come out lately and it's obvious that this issue is growing. . .I
> want to help other people with this who may think they have it or know or
> whatever, a lot of people with this become suicidal or commit suicide due
to
> the difficulty finding help in any sort. Thats the main reason I agreed to
> be on a news bit about it. I don't care what people think about me, but I
> don't want people to have to go thru what I know I've been thru. . .
>
> I can expain more later, but this is very long already. . .
>
> take care all
> : )

> > > > I think this is a serious issue for people like us, who frequent
> parties
> > > > with large numbers of close quartered people, in old wherehouses,
> buildings,
> > > > and areas that are likely to be heavily infested with these
creatures.
> > >
> > > Do you have an specific reason to believe that the parasites are
> > > transmitted simply from being in close quarters with other people? Or
> > > that the parasites live in old warehouses or buildings? Has there been
> > > research on the mode of transmission?
> > >
> >
> > I think that aK is mistaken as to the vector. On the morgellons.org
> > website, a page talks about how a significant majority of those
suffering
> > from this outbreak also test positive for the BB bacteria that causes
Lyme
> > disease, which is, as you should know from your cynical epidemiologist
> > hat, a disease that is not as well understood as some others and which
> > does seem to have some undetermined function against the immune system.
> > Lyme disease, though, is fairly well traceable to a certain tick, which
> > might mean that there's a chance that OUTDOOR parties are a risk.
> >
> > All in all, it's something to keep on the back burner for awhile, I
think.
> > aK is (semi)obviously a little more prone to the conspiracy theory than
> > most of us are. Not to say he/she/it's a liar, not at all. Just that we
> > need more evidence or even more verifiable anecdotes and reserve
judgment
> > until then.
> >
> > I bet it's more real than the Chupacabra, though.
> >
> > -jon
> >
> >
>
>
>

 sfraves@hyperreal.org
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20040224172942.GC9267@atari.saturn5.com>
Message-Id: <A444A71E-6769-11D8-910E-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Re: the climate change scare & the AIDS scare -- less reason to worry than they told us

On Tuesday, February 24, 2004, at 09:29  AM, Troy Sheets wrote:

> Well, the thing about climate change, is that we won't know for sure 
> 100%
> until it is too late and irreversable.

	We don't know for sure 100% that Martians aren't planning to invade 
Earth, either. But we do know, about as surely as we know anything 
where the economy is concerned, that implementing the Kyoto regulations 
will be an economic disaster, cost billions of dollars and millions of 
jobs, and have innumerable side effects such as poorer nutrition, less 
access to education and health care, higher mortality rates, and other 
conditions that are more prevalent when people are poorer -- which most 
of us will be if we give in to this fear-mongering.

	What makes you think climate change is irreversible, anyway? Are you 
saying that humans are now making the planet warmer without even 
trying, but there's no way to make it cooler even if we deliberately 
seek that result? As noted in the article I sent, the scare back in the 
60s was in fact "global cooling" -- the alarmists were full of warnings 
that human activity was making the planet colder. When it turned out 
that in fact the planet was getting slightly warmer, they had to 
abandon that scare and switch to crying wolf about "global warming."

> And I know for a fact that if/when SOMA is under 10 feet of water, 
> there
> will still be people saying "The ocean's 20 foot rise is simply a 
> nature
> cycle of the planet..."

	And if such a thing *were* to occur -- which is *extremely* doubtful 
-- those people could be right that it was a natural cycle of the 
planet. Geological evidence shows that the earth's climate *has* 
changed in the past, before humans were ever in the picture. Given that 
this has happened before, many times, why should we assume now that 
it's all humanity's fault when there is no concrete evidence of it?

	For those who actually believe that humans are a "cancer on the 
planet," which is what a lot of this non-science basically boils down 
to -- the Church of Euthanasia wants YOU as a member!  
http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/

> Any cost we incur now to help prevent possible global climate change 
> will
> be a mere fraction of what the costs will be if the dire predictions 
> are
> correct.

	Fortunately the dire predictions appear to have little scientific 
basis. The global warming scare is the international equivalent of the 
U.S. government urging people to wrap their homes in duct tape after 
the September 11 attacks. Remember that precautionary advice? Did 
anyone on this list go out and buy a bunch of duct tape? If so, are you 
feeling a bit foolish now, thinking about it? Want to be fooled all 
over again, but have it cost you a lot more money this time? Then by 
all means, support the fight against global warming.

Peace, love & liberty,
							<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] I'm Mad as Hell

I understand the frustration of Bush not facing the people upon whose
lives he is affecting and denying the right to be human. But as a
presidential candidate you don't go and try to win voters over when you
have pissed them off. You go to areas where people support you and
ensure the ideas of the pissed off people do not affect them. 

As for protesting and yelling fuck you it is very anti-productive in the
way of protesting. If you have something to say put it in a way that
people will listen to. If I walk up to you and start saying "fuck you"
"you piss me off" then what will you do probably get defensive and ready
to attack but if I attack your character in a personable and educated
way you are practically forced to answer otherwise in front of your
supporters you look like a dumaus. 

Just my .02 


Jason

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed

This isn't an abnormal amount of rain.  It just happened to rain really 
_quickly_ last night and this morning, and the drainage systems aren't 
up to handling that much flow.
The scary thing about global warming isn't just that it raises sea 
levels. (which isn't due to more rain, but rather melting ice caps) 
Global warming will alter global weather patterns, making some places 
wetter and also some drier.  Regardless of whether or not SF ends up 
under water in 100 years, i think it would suck if, say, much of the 
pacific northwest became a vast sahara style desert.  But then, it might 
be kinda nice if it were wetter in LA.
ben
JonnyR@aol.com wrote:

>ok ... we all agree it's raining a lot. How about some synthesis ... why is 
>it raining so much? Does it have to do with global warming, or is this just a 
>natural amount of rain?  When you step in a 6" puddle, does it feel any warmer 
>than last year's 6" puddle?    :)   Just stirring things up! 
>
>  
>

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 http://mokshatribe.org/photos/

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"What difference does it make to the dead, the orphans and the homeless, 
whether the mad destruction is wrought under the name of totalitarianism or 
the holy name of liberty or democracy?"
-Mahatma Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

You have a lot to learn about the social dynamics of sfraves...

You say something that has a cheerleader *ra ra* sound to it - expect to get
jumped on.
You say something dumb or that can be easily turned around into something
cynical or sarcastic - you'll get just that kind of response.
If you ever mention the acronym *plur* on here - you're gong to be laughed
at like you wouldn't believe.

:: licks+lollipops ::

Jay Dehd

innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com> wrote:You have a lot to learn about the social dynamics of sfraves...

You say something that has a cheerleader *ra ra* sound to it - expect to get
jumped on.
You say something dumb or that can be easily turned around into something
cynical or sarcastic - you'll get just that kind of response.
If you ever mention the acronym *plur* on here - you're gong to be laughed
at like you wouldn't believe.

:: licks+lollipops ::

Jay Dehd

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) Booty, Breaks and Balaclavas, Friday, March 12

PLEASE FORWARD WIDELY

BOOTY, BREAK AND BALACLAVAS

Outdoor DJ area at the 7th Annual Anarchist Cafe

featuring DJs Tomkat (Subversive Soundz, SPAZ), Morse
Code (Subversive Soundz) and J. Clang (Havoc)

booty, breaks, techno, downtempo, plus

Friday, March 12, 2004
entire event: 6pm to midnight
DJs and dancing: 9pm to midnight

at "The Kitchen"
225 Portrero Ave., at 16th Street
San Francisco

A benefit for The Bay Area Anarchist Bookfair
and political prisoner Sherman Austin 

$5 - $15 donation requested
No one turned away for lack of funds

INDOOR PERFORMANCE AREA including
music, guest speakers, spoken word, and poetry

"BOOTY, BREAKS AND BALACLAVAS" 
OUTDOOR DJ AREA by Subversive Soundz 
 
VIDEO by Video Activist Network 

dinner 6:30
performers indoors 7-10
video 8-9
dancing 9 ‘til midnight

all ages!  kid friendly!

drug and alcohol free space.
wheelchair accessible.   

The Bay Area Anarchist Bookfair, now in its ninth
year, takes places on Saturday, March 13 from 10am to
6pm at the S.F. County Fair Building on 9th Avenue in
Golden Gate Park.  Admission is free, and speakers
include Starhawk, Alexander Cockburn, Jeffrey St.
Clair, Lynn Breedlove, Tim’M T. West, Katya Komisaruk,
Agent Apple of the Biotic Baking Brigade, Susan
Greene, Sun Frog and Sean Sullivan.  For more
information call (415) 431-8355.

Sherman Austin, a 20 year-old, black, Southern
California anarchist, was the webmaster of the site
www.raisethefist.com. He is the first person to be
charged under 18 U.S.C. 842(p), a 1997
"anti-terrorism" law authored by California Senator
Dianne Feinstein.  What was Austin’s crime?  He had
had offered free hosting and a link on his website to
a site called The Reclaim Guide, offering general
security culture information along with a small
portion dealing with explosives, authored by a young
white person from a wealthy, conservative family. 
This information is publicly available, and Austin
merely linked to it, yet he is being jailed for it.  

On August 4, Sherman Austin was sentened to one year
in federal prison and three years probation.  His
probation includes the following terms: Austin cannot
possess or access a computer of any kind without prior
approval of his probation officer; if he gets that
approval, the equipment is subject to monitoring and
to search and seizure at any time, without notice; he
must surrender his phone, DSL, electric, and satellite
bills to his probation officer; and he cannot
associate with any person or group--environmental,
social justice, political, or economic--that seeks to
change the government in any way.

Although Austin initially planned to fight the charge
and go to trial, he accepted a plea bargain after
being threatened with serving up to 20 years in jail.
Despite both the FBI and the Justice Department
agreeing on a sentence of four months in jail and four
months in community confinement, the judge increased
the sentence to set an example for future
"revolutionaries."  


For more information about Sherman Austin, please see:

www.freesherman.org
http://www.counterpunch.org/merlin08162003.html
http://rwor.org/a/1217/austin.htm
http://www.infoshop.org/shermanaustin.html


__________________________________

http://antispam.yahoo.com/tools

Subject: [sfraves] bsp- John Howard & JZ this saturday 2.28 "mOOv"

mOOv with John Howard this Saturday @ Luna Lounge

Same great monthly with a whole new identity. SF-Vibe invites you back to Luna Lounge February 28th AND every 4th Saturday of the month for mOOv. 

And what better way to establish this new identity than with our old friend and master crowd pleaser, John Howard (OM Records). It's always a treat to have John share his energy and passion with us. Those of you who've experienced him know what we're talkin' about. Joining John in the main room is one of our favorite local heros, JZ (Red Melon), as well as SF-Vibe resident Todd Michael. For you lovers of the quality sounds of yesteryear, the goods will be served up to your liking courtesy Andy T (Space Cowboys), Chad Mitchell (Roam Recordings, SF-Vibe) and Cameron (Good Beats). 

Hit the site before Saturday to sign-up for the VIP list, and as long as you're there you might as well check out previous month's pics to see old friends, see what ya missed or refresh that fading long term memory :-) 

http://www.sf-vibe.com

love,
JOnas

At 02:34 PM 2/25/2004, SE/30 wrote:
>a fool eh ?  sure, if *after* they'd clicked and read the first line.

Ah, Dave.  Now that I've cleaned all the sewage out of my garage I can deal 
with you:)  It is revealing, isn't it, that anyone would believe our 
beloved leader would say something stupid like:  "Gays Ruined Valentine's 
Day?"  Funny I just sent out another informative article to a different 
list titled "Bush Lies Uncovered."  That pretty much sums it all up:)


>but up until that point, and even after the page started loading (didn't 
>even check the url before clicking) it appeared to be some actual news 
>article reporting president Bush stating what you made it appear he said 
>in your subject.
>
>after reading the first line, i felt like i was duped by a clever 
>marketing spam that ended in a game of viagra-pop-up-window-killer.

Well, Dave, I spent much of my life in business as a marketing person but, 
lest I be accused of plagiarism, the head came from someone on another 
rave-related list.


>oh well, that will teach me to read your "informative" posts...

But much of this satire was informative, to my mind, especially the piece 
about what a constitutional amendment might look like.

Bush said : "If we are to prevent the meaning of marriage from being 
changed forever, our nation must enact a constitutional amendment to 
protect marriage in America."  If one bases the definition of marriage, as 
the satire suggests, on the Old and New Testaments you might find some 
problems.

What is that "meaning of marriage?"  If one looks at the Old Testament one 
would think the model for marriage is polygamy.  In the New Testament 
marriage itself has mixed reviews.  Paul says:  "Marriage is not a sin, but 
it is better to remain unmarried."  In the Church marriage didn't become a 
sacred sacrament until the 12th century.  Before that in Europe there were 
civil unions.

Marriage in America.  Yes.  California was the first state to allow 
interracial marriages in 1948.  Before that it was illegal, and didn't 
become legal in all of the States until the Supreme Court ruling in 
1967.  In that ruling Chief Justice Earl Warren wrote:  "...the freedom to 
marry or not to marry a person of another race resides in that 
individual."  He refers to "person," not man or woman, throughout that opinion.

Women and marriage in America.  In the 1700s and 1800s married women lost 
many legal rights when they said "I do."  They could not own property, pay 
taxes, or sign contracts.  All monies earned had to be turned over to the 
husband.  The woman, in effect, became a possession of the man.  Only until 
the late 19th century did this begin to change and as recently as 1920 
Arizona, Florida, Louisiana and New Mexico still had those unjust laws on 
the books.

One could go on.  Seems to me this is all about semantics.  When a man and 
woman decide to marry they go to a government office to get a 
license.  Then they make a decision:  be "joined" by the state, or 
"married" by the church of their choice.  The same could apply to gay 
couples.  There are churches that do marry gay couples, or they could be 
joined by a civil union.  Whatever, some constitutional definition of a 
muddy religious term -- "marriage"  -- by the state in inappropriate here 
and clearly against the equal protection intent of federal and many state 
constitutions.

In Germany, France, Canada and Vermont, state-sanctioned unions help gay 
couples clarify the legal status and rights of their partnership in 
everything from bank accounts to hospital visitation to child custody. For 
gays seeking these rights elsewhere, this is primarily a practical 
struggle, and it is wrong for the President to exploit it for political 
purposes.


Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 http://mokshatribe.org/photos/

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"What difference does it make to the dead, the orphans and the homeless, 
whether the mad destruction is wrought under the name of totalitarianism or 
the holy name of liberty or democracy?"
-Mahatma Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Right on, Warren. Your heart is in the right place. 

We may have had a gay president before. Well, we might have had several, for 
all we know, but James Buchanan is the only President who never married. His 
sister served as First Lady. These uptight days, though, it's hard to imagine 
having a gay president. (Someday there will be a male "Monica" to get a 
president in trouble -- mark my words!)

There are other rights issues I would prefer to tackle before "gay marriage." 
But it's out there now, and it seems like it will lead to at least civil 
unions across the US, if not full-fledged marriage. There seems to be a lot of 
sentiment to leave it up to each state.

interestingly, he was a Republican - Abraham Lincoln
(the evidence is there - it may be many more decades before it all comes out)

I started a pretty reactive thread, yesterday with my "I'm Mad As Hell" post -

Just to make sure that no one is mistaken about the appropriateness of that 
post
to this list . . . sfraves and the community we have continued to be for 
over a decade
has always been about stalking and experiencing as much freedom as we could 
handle
with hopefully no one getting hurt along the way.   The erosion of our 
civil liberties over
just 3 years and the fear of what even 4 more seasons of Ashcroft should 
engender amongst us . . . .

Many of us remember how easy it was to do an all-night renegade - outside - 
on the beach, even - and have it go off
with no hassles whatsoever - how many of those have any of us attended in 
the past
couple of years ?  especially those attracting several hundred 
people  ?   for super cheap or free ?

I've been around a LONG time (OK - not as long as Apollo, but close ; )

I have had the personal opportunity to protest Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Bush # 
1 and now, Bush # 2
and as for the "thank god he has alzheimer's - too bad it took so long to 
diagnose" Reagan

I have never experienced as abusive an idiot in the White House as The 
Great Divider

To those who question the wisdom of peaceful organized groups gathering 
together to
question the decisions and even the authority of "those in power" to sing 
in unison
anthems like "This Land is Your Land" or, even ironically The National 
Anthem is, in fact,
a way of saying F*** YOU to whatever is being protested at that time.

I have done it many many many times - and it feels really good.
Marching down Market Street early last year - FELT REALLY GOOD -
lots of voices, joined together - have power - and feeling yourself as part 
of that power
is to elevate your sense of self as a human being - we've all felt it after 
many hours on the dancefloor.

And if it makes the news . . . well, yes, mr faceless shouting their fool 
head off protestor/freak - you win !
Because !!!!
Nobody wants to look bad on the evening news - (none even President Gas 
(Psyc Furs reference !) - it affects the polls.

Thanks to those of you with great ideas (you'll be hearing from me)
and thanks to the rest for reading and commenting.

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v612)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <CC2C5849-6814-11D8-8467-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org,
 micromu@sbcglobal.net
From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 25 Feb 2004 20:32:34 -0800
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.612)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Enough is bein SAID...What are we goin to DO?

With regard to the "back room deals" and general corruption, I defy you 
to give an example of a similar-sized economy that has significantly 
less.  Sure, ideally, such corruption would be rooted out and stopped.  
But the cynical part of me believes that, humans being humans, power 
corrupts; and a certian amount of corruption is inevitable.

I do, however, firmly believe that the more distant the government, the 
worse the government; and that local government will always respond 
better to the needs and wants of the people than some far-off overlord.

But as far as the taxation issue goes, you're dead wrong.  You'd do 
well to check out this page:

http://www.bcnys.org/whatsnew/2001/1211balance.htm

Californians pay over 63 BILLION dollars more in federal taxes, per 
year, than the state gets back in federal money!  That's "billion" with 
the big "B"!!!  Sixty-three of them!

Fiscally, California could easily do without the rest of the US.  In 
fact, we'd be far better off without them.  If California were to 
secede from the US... If that money were kept in California, instead of 
being leached off to feed a bunch of the more parasitic of the states, 
California could easily:

1) Make up for the federal money we'd lose (much LESS than we pay to 
DC, remember)
2) Balance our state budget
3) Boost a lot of our social services
4) And STILL have enough left to give Californians a big honkin' 
(overall) tax break!

Sure, some of that money would still be lost to corruption and your 
"back room deals".  But it would be lost in Sacramento instead of 
washington.  And it's much easier to notice corruption when it''s an 
hour's drive up the 80 than when it's three-thousand miles away.  It's 
much easier to find out about it, and with California's more direct 
democracy (via the proposition and recall systems) it's much easier to 
root it out, as Grey Davis found out just a few months ago.  (Imagine 
just how short the bush/ashcroft regime would have been, if the ability 
to recall the chief executive (and various hangers-on) existed, at the 
national level, as it does here.)

When you come right down to it, Scott is 100% correct.  Regardless of 
some of the shady things that go on in California; they pale in 
comparison to the rest of the blighted country.  And we'd be far better 
off without the rest of the US dragging us down, slowing us down, and 
suckling at the teat of our tax dollars; all the while hating us for 
socially progressing farther ahead than them.


cya,
john

"micromu" wrote:

 > Yeah, our ideals sure have.  8.xx% state sales tax; and rising
 > Car taxes (nearly) 300% more than the already outrageous
 > amount we pay.  Back room deals and swindles.  San Jose,
 > for example, claiming emminent domain to get some houses
 > that are "a blight" on the cheap.  The list goes on.
 > Remove the "P" and replace the "O", keep the "GRESSIVE"
 > and you've got CA summed up pretty well, imo.

John,

	I haven't lost *my* appreciation for candy ravers. And people taking 
"PLUR" seriously is something I miss. But that's an interesting point 
about Internet communities becoming jaded over time. What can be done 
about it? We could try to care less about seniority (who's been around 
the longest or who did something first) and simply value people and 
their contributions as they come.

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Secession

	It's not just distance from the people that makes a government worse. 
It's how much power a government has over their lives. Governments with 
more power tend to be more corrupt, because -- as John said -- power 
corrupts.

	I agree that California secession is worth considering. Secession.net 
(http://www.secession.net/) is a good resource on the issue of 
secession in general.

Peace, Love, & Liberty,
						<<< Starchild >>>


On Wednesday, February 25, 2004, at 08:32  PM, John B. wrote:

> With regard to the "back room deals" and general corruption, I defy 
> you to give an example of a similar-sized economy that has 
> significantly less.  Sure, ideally, such corruption would be rooted 
> out and stopped.  But the cynical part of me believes that, humans 
> being humans, power corrupts; and a certian amount of corruption is 
> inevitable.
>
> I do, however, firmly believe that the more distant the government, 
> the worse the government; and that local government will always 
> respond better to the needs and wants of the people than some far-off 
> overlord.
>
> But as far as the taxation issue goes, you're dead wrong.  You'd do 
> well to check out this page:
>
> http://www.bcnys.org/whatsnew/2001/1211balance.htm
>
> Californians pay over 63 BILLION dollars more in federal taxes, per 
> year, than the state gets back in federal money!  That's "billion" 
> with the big "B"!!!  Sixty-three of them!
>
> Fiscally, California could easily do without the rest of the US.  In 
> fact, we'd be far better off without them.  If California were to 
> secede from the US... If that money were kept in California, instead 
> of being leached off to feed a bunch of the more parasitic of the 
> states, California could easily:
>
> 1) Make up for the federal money we'd lose (much LESS than we pay to 
> DC, remember)
> 2) Balance our state budget
> 3) Boost a lot of our social services
> 4) And STILL have enough left to give Californians a big honkin' 
> (overall) tax break!
>
> Sure, some of that money would still be lost to corruption and your 
> "back room deals".  But it would be lost in Sacramento instead of 
> washington.  And it's much easier to notice corruption when it''s an 
> hour's drive up the 80 than when it's three-thousand miles away.  It's 
> much easier to find out about it, and with California's more direct 
> democracy (via the proposition and recall systems) it's much easier to 
> root it out, as Grey Davis found out just a few months ago.  (Imagine 
> just how short the bush/ashcroft regime would have been, if the 
> ability to recall the chief executive (and various hangers-on) 
> existed, at the national level, as it does here.)
>
> When you come right down to it, Scott is 100% correct.  Regardless of 
> some of the shady things that go on in California; they pale in 
> comparison to the rest of the blighted country.  And we'd be far 
> better off without the rest of the US dragging us down, slowing us 
> down, and suckling at the teat of our tax dollars; all the while 
> hating us for socially progressing farther ahead than them.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
> "micromu" wrote:
>
> > Yeah, our ideals sure have.  8.xx% state sales tax; and rising
> > Car taxes (nearly) 300% more than the already outrageous
> > amount we pay.  Back room deals and swindles.  San Jose,
> > for example, claiming emminent domain to get some houses
> > that are "a blight" on the cheap.  The list goes on.
> > Remove the "P" and replace the "O", keep the "GRESSIVE"
> > and you've got CA summed up pretty well, imo.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Enough is bein SAID...What are we goin to DO?

Well, I once heard Ryan make a VERY good argument against "plur", in 
that it had become a commercialized slogan and empty, over-used, 
tagline that should be unnecessary if you actually DO try to live by 
it.

And I have to say, I kind of agree.  All the pre-made candy necklaces 
with "plur" spelled out in letter beads you can buy from a vendor at a 
coolworld massive don't mean jack if you don't treat your fellow ravers 
right.

Hell, I still *DO* go out to parties all candied-up, every so often.  
More than a few people have seen me as such.  And I can't recall the 
last time I said or wrote "plur", except in a discussion like this, or 
in a goofy self-deprecating way.  But that dosn't mean that I don't try 
my best to treat fellow ravers that way.

Peace, love, unity, and respect are fine ideals to live by.  "Plur" is 
a fine concept to take seriously; and, IMO, a better philosophy than 
most.  But I don't need to put it on a t-shirt to try* to live up to 
the ideal.

*And yeah, sometimes I've failed to do so.


cya,
john

From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 26 Feb 2004 00:04:15 -0800
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.612)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RE: Groove on IFC right now

One of the fun things about watching Groove, for me, is an exercise in 
"then and now" contrasts.

When Groove first came out, I had just moved to San Francisco, and I 
barely knew anyone here, in the rave scene or otherwise.  So I watched 
Groove, and, okay, it was a nifty little movie about a party.  I wasn't 
really into raves, at the time, but hey.... it'd be cool if parties 
like that really happened.  I wonder how close to the *real* rave scene 
it is.

Fast-forward four years....

Now, whenever I watch Groove, I catch myself intently watching all the 
party scenes, looking for people I've gotten to know in the meantime; 
and occasionally finding them.  That, and looking for familiar people 
and groups to be mentioned in the credits or special features on the 
disc.  And looking for familiar roads/buildings/etc.


cya,
john

On Feb 26, 2004, at 12:04 AM, John B. wrote:

> One of the fun things about watching Groove, for me, is an exercise in 
> "then and now" contrasts.
>
> When Groove first came out, I had just moved to San Francisco, and I 
> barely knew anyone here, in the rave scene or otherwise.  So I watched 
> Groove, and, okay, it was a nifty little movie about a party.  I 
> wasn't really into raves, at the time, but hey.... it'd be cool if 
> parties like that really happened.  I wonder how close to the *real* 
> rave scene it is.
>
> Fast-forward four years....
>
> Now, whenever I watch Groove, I catch myself intently watching all the 
> party scenes, looking for people I've gotten to know in the meantime; 
> and occasionally finding them.  That, and looking for familiar people 
> and groups to be mentioned in the credits or special features on the 
> disc.  And looking for familiar roads/buildings/etc.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] FRIDAY: SOMA Sessions D&B w/NOOKIE (Good Looking-UK)

SOMA Sessions 
Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF
http://www.somasessions.com


THIS FRIDAY - February 27, 2004 

As featured in the SF Weekly's Beatbox column, this
month SOMA Sessions is proud to welcome...

NOOKIE (Good Looking Records - UK)

With countless releases on Reinforced, Moving Shadow
and LTJ Bukem's Good Looking, Nookie's style and
artistic vision have pushed the boundaries of Drum &
Bass leaving countless classics in his wake.  His
highly sought-after talents as a producer, engineer,
remixer and DJ have taken him around the world many
times.  SOMA Sessions is excited and honored to host
this seminal artist for an evening of amazing music.

ULTRAVIOLET (Sleeveless, SF Agency)

UltraViolet is known to level dance floors with her
wide range of styles and fierce skills. This founding
member of the notorious Sleeveless collective is not
to be missed!

Resident Support: 

DJ M (SOMA Sessions, Faultline, Freebeats)

SOUND:BOY (SOMA Sessions, Hemisphere, Brass Tax)


** Discount presale tickets have sold out but there
will be $15 tickets available at the door! **

Hours: 10:30pm - 3am
Entry: 21+ with photo ID
Tickets: $10 presale, $15 door
Drink specials: $3 Lemon Drop shots all night!

To sign up on our mailing list or for more info, visit
http://somasessions.com

AsiaSF 
201 Ninth Street at Howard St 
San Francisco, California 94103 

AsiaSF serves 3-Star Cal-Asian cuisine in a festive
and stylish atmosphere.  For Sunday through Thursday
dinner reservations, please call 415.255.ASIA(2742)
from 1pm to 8pm or visit http://www.asiasf.com.

SOMA branding & print design by Ryan @ Citizen-7
http://www.citizen-7.com/


NEXT MONTH - Friday March 26, 2004
_ ASC (Covert Operations - UK)
_ Illformants (Breakbeat Science, Subtitles)

Subject: =?ISO-8859-1?Q?Re:=20[sfraves]=20What=20are=20your=20favorite=20?=
 =?ISO-8859-1?Q?type=20of=20shoes=3F=BF=3F?=

-------------------------------1077818913
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Skate shoes in general for me. My favorite is ES, but there's not much 
difference between them and Etnies or Emerica, as they're the same company. Really 
comfy, with all that padding on the tongue, and they have a removable sole 
insert with good support.  They make the feet look big, which seems to be an 
advantage over small feet for some reason ;)

The teenage character Jeremy in the SF Chron comic strip "Zits" wears 
oversized skate shoes, and the cartoonist says kids always comment that he has cool 
shoes.

If you want your feet to look long, wear K-Swiss along with straight-leg 
jeans. The feet will look long and skinny. 

-------------------------------1077818913--

hand. All set against the backdrop of the worlds largest cargo cranes in the

Subject: RE: [sfraves] What are your favorite type of shoes?¿?

Adidas Shelltoes (aka Superstars)

I've been rockin' shelltoes since around '86, and even though I have bought 
New Balance (which are also nice), and Skechers (more for pimpin'), I will 
ALWAYS have at LEAST one pair of Shelltoes on hand. They are the absolute 
shiz-nit. Perfect grip for any dancefloor, comfy, relatively reasonably 
priced if you know where to look, and come in a variety of color schemes for 
maximum matching-to-clothing ability.

ez.

Marc(O)

Received: (qmail 30060 invoked from network); 26 Feb 2004 19:22:57 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [67.125.255.38]
X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org, djseraphim@yahoo.com
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 26 Feb 2004 11:22:54 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F70M9wGmAf0Mjk000056cb@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 26 Feb 2004 19:22:54.0910 (UTC) FILETIME=[EF2A55E0:01C3FC9D]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] RE: Groove on IFC right now

I fucking love GROOVE personally. Coming from the East Coast, where Groove 
is considered to be "complete and toal bullshit" and "not even slightly 
realistic", I was SUPREMELY happy to find upon moving out here, that it's a 
HELLUVA lot closer to reality then I could have ever imagined. The Bay Area 
still has a good sense of community, and a pretty damn good attitude 
overall. There's a MUCH wider range of diversity and a larger sense of 
"giving something back" to the "scene" (as it were).

I consistantly rub it in my DC peeps' faces too - much to their dismay. 
DC/Baltimore USED to be like that - and then everyone started getting wacked 
on meth, and playing "uber-scenster" and now it's pretty lame out there. The 
ONLY thing they have going for them is BUZZ (run by Scott Henry and John 
Tab). Don't get me wrong, it's a bad ass weekly at a HUGE venue, with 
amazing talent and excellent sound. But the VIBE just isn't consistant.

I'm soooooooooooo happy I'm out here, and that I get to rediscover over and 
over again why I got into this shit in the 1st place...

Marc(O)


>From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, djseraphim@yahoo.com
>Subject: [sfraves] RE: Groove on IFC right now
>Date: Thu, 26 Feb 2004 00:04:15 -0800
>
>One of the fun things about watching Groove, for me, is an exercise in 
>"then and now" contrasts.
>
>When Groove first came out, I had just moved to San Francisco, and I barely 
>knew anyone here, in the rave scene or otherwise.  So I watched Groove, 
>and, okay, it was a nifty little movie about a party.  I wasn't really into 
>raves, at the time, but hey.... it'd be cool if parties like that really 
>happened.  I wonder how close to the *real* rave scene it is.
>
>Fast-forward four years....
>
>Now, whenever I watch Groove, I catch myself intently watching all the 
>party scenes, looking for people I've gotten to know in the meantime; and 
>occasionally finding them.  That, and looking for familiar people and 
>groups to be mentioned in the credits or special features on the disc.  And 
>looking for familiar roads/buildings/etc.
>
>
>cya,
>john
>

takes a while tho).

X-ELNK-Trace: 3dff75ed0343effeee26750b534f88a60a9da525759e26546e154b678dbf067ba5ee7874b85ed9e7f83aa984341be17f350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] - next tues, 3/2: MATTHEW DEAR @ club six

For anyone who complains that there's no techno in SF, next Tuesday, 3/2 is
a chance to set the record straight. We're bringing Detroit's MATTHEW DEAR
to Club Six for a night of the finest minimal techno and microhouse.

You may know Dear from his recent album "Dog Days" on Ghostly
International/Spectral Sounds, or perhaps for his records for Richie
Hawtin's Minus/Plus8 label (as FALSE) and Berlin's Perlon label (as
JABBERJAW).

Dude's stuff is minimal, slinky, bubbly and ridiculously funky, and it's
been hailed by XLR8R, URB, The Wire, Vice, and many others. If you dig the
Perlon/Playhouse/Kompakt minimal-but-funky sound, you definitely should
swing by.

Support acts are L'usine (Ghostly) and DJs Aktual Jakshun (Proptronix) and
me, Philip Sherburne (Trouble/XLR8R).

Full deets:


http://www.404404.com/konstrukt/

Tuesday, March 2nd
Recombinant and Konstrukt present:
Ghostly International Tour (http://www.ghostly.com)
MATTHEW DEAR (ghostly international, perlon)
L'USINE (ghostly international, isophlux)

AKTUAL JAKSHUN (proptronix, incomplet)
@ Club Six
9pm - 2am
$10


Thanks!
Philip
